House File 2063 - Introduced


                                 HOUSE FILE 

                                 HOUSE FILE 
                                 HOUSE FILE                                  HOUSE FILE                                  BY  ISENHART

 A BILL FOR

  1 An Act providing for benefit corporations, and providing for
  2    fees.
  3 BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF THE STATE OF IOWA:
    TLSB 5453YH (2) 86
    da/nh

  1  1                          SUBCHAPTER I

  1  3    Section 1.  

  1  1                          SUBCHAPTER I
  1  2                     PRELIMINARY PROVISIONS
  1  3    Section 1.  
  1  1                          SUBCHAPTER I
  1  2                     PRELIMINARY PROVISIONS
  1  3    Section 1.    1  1                          SUBCHAPTER I
  1  2                     PRELIMINARY PROVISIONS
  1  3    Section 1.    1  2                     PRELIMINARY PROVISIONS
  1  3    Section 1.    1  3    Section 1.    1  4    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Iowa
  1  5 Benefit Corporation Act".
  1  6    Sec. 2.    1  5 Benefit Corporation Act".
  1  6    Sec. 2.    1  6    Sec. 2.    1  7    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, or unless the
  1  8 context otherwise requires, the words and phrases used in this
  1  9 chapter shall have the same meaning as the words and phrases
  1 10 used in chapter 490, including but not limited to the words
  1 11 and phrases used in section 490.140.  In addition, all of the
  1 12 following shall apply:
  1 13    1.  "Benefit corporation" means a business corporation, if
  1 14 all of the following apply:
  1 15    a.  It has elected to become subject to this chapter.
  1 16    b.  Its status as a benefit corporation has not been
  1 17 terminated.
  1 18    2.  "Benefit director" means a director designated as
  1 19 the benefit director of a benefit corporation under section
  1 20 490B.302.
  1 21    3.  "Benefit enforcement proceeding" means a claim or action
  1 22 relating to any of the following:
  1 23    a.  The failure of a benefit corporation to pursue or create
  1 24 general public benefit or a specific public benefit set forth
  1 25 in its articles of incorporation.
  1 26    b.  A violation of any obligation, duty, or standard of
  1 27 conduct provided under this chapter.
  1 28    4.  "Benefit officer" means an individual designated as
  1 29 the benefit officer of a benefit corporation under section
  1 30 490B.304.
  1 31    5.  "Business corporation" means a corporation formed as a
  1 32 domestic corporation under chapter 490.
  1 33    6.  "Entity" means a person formed under the laws of
  1 34 this state including but not limited to a limited liability
  1 35 company under chapter 489; a corporation under chapter 490;
  2  1 a nonprofit corporation under chapter 504; a partnership,
  2  2 limited partnership, limited liability partnership, or limited
  2  3 liability limited partnership under chapter 486A or 488; or a
  2  4 cooperative association or other cooperative organized under
  2  5 chapter 497, 498, 499, 501, or 501A.
  2  6    7.  "General public benefit" means a material positive impact
  2  7 on society and the environment, taken as a whole, assessed
  2  8 against a third=party standard, which results from the business
  2  9 and operations of a benefit corporation.
  2 10    8.  "Independent" means having no material relationship
  2 11 with a benefit corporation or a subsidiary of the benefit
  2 12 corporation as provided in section 490B.304A.
  2 13    9.  "Minimum status vote" means any of the following:
  2 14    a.  In the case of a business corporation, in addition to any
  2 15 other required approval or vote required under chapter 490, the
  2 16 satisfaction of all of the following conditions:
  2 17    (1)  The shareholders of every class or series are
  2 18 entitled to vote as a separate voting group on the corporate
  2 19 action regardless of a limitation stated in the articles of
  2 20 incorporation or bylaws regarding the voting rights of any
  2 21 class or series.
  2 22    (2)  The corporate action is approved by vote of the
  2 23 shareholders of each class or series entitled to cast at least
  2 24 two=thirds of the votes that all shareholders of the class or
  2 25 series are entitled to cast on the action.
  2 26    b.  In the case of an entity other than a business
  2 27 corporation, in addition to any other required approval, vote,
  2 28 or consent, the satisfaction of all the following conditions:
  2 29    (1)  The holders of every class or series of equity interest
  2 30 in the entity that are entitled to receive a distribution of
  2 31 any kind from the entity are entitled to vote on or consent to
  2 32 the action regardless of any otherwise applicable limitation on
  2 33 the voting or consent rights of any class or series.
  2 34    (2)  The action  is approved by vote or consent of the
  2 35 holders described in subparagraph (1) entitled to cast at least
  3  1 two=thirds of the votes or consents that all of those holders
  3  2 are entitled to cast on the action.
  3  3    10.  "Specific public benefit" means any of the following:
  3  4    a.  Providing low=income or underserved individuals or
  3  5 communities with beneficial products or services.
  3  6    b.  Promoting economic opportunity for individuals or
  3  7 communities beyond the creation of jobs in the normal course
  3  8 of business.
  3  9    c.  Protecting or restoring the environment.
  3 10    d.  Improving human health.
  3 11    e.  Promoting the arts, sciences, or advancement of
  3 12 knowledge.
  3 13    f.  Increasing  the flow of capital to entities with a purpose
  3 14 to benefit society or the environment.
  3 15    g.  Conferring any other particular benefit on society or the
  3 16 environment.
  3 17    11.  "Subsidiary" means, in relation to a person, an entity
  3 18 in which the person holds beneficially or of record  fifty
  3 19 percent  or more of the outstanding equity interests.
  3 20    12.  "Third=party standard" means a recognized standard
  3 21 for defining, reporting, and assessing corporate social or
  3 22 environmental performance that is all of the following:
  3 23    a.  Comprehensive because the standard assesses the effect of
  3 24 the business and its operations upon the interests listed in
  3 25 section 490B.301, subsection 1, paragraphs "b" through "e".
  3 26    b.  Developed by an entity that is not controlled by the
  3 27 benefit corporation.
  3 28    c.  Credible because the standard is developed by an entity
  3 29 that meets all of the following conditions:
  3 30    (1)  Has access to necessary expertise to assess overall
  3 31 corporate social or environmental performance.
  3 32    (2)  Uses a balanced multiple stakeholder approach to
  3 33 develop the standard, including a reasonable public comment
  3 34 period.
  3 35    d.  Transparent because the following information is made
  4  1 publicly available:
  4  2    (1)  A description of the standard that includes all of the
  4  3 following:
  4  4    (a)  Criteria considered when measuring the overall social
  4  5 or environmental performance of a business corporation.
  4  6    (b)  The relative weightings, if any, of  the criteria
  4  7 described in subparagraph division (a).
  4  8    (2)  A description of the development and revision of the
  4  9 standard which includes all of the following:
  4 10    (a)  The identity of the directors, officers, material
  4 11 owners, and the governing body of the entity that developed and
  4 12 controls revisions to the standard.
  4 13    (b)  The process by which revisions to the standard and
  4 14 changes to the membership of the governing body are made.
  4 15    (c)  An accounting of the revenue and sources of financial
  4 16 support for the entity, with sufficient detail to disclose any
  4 17 relationship that could reasonably be considered to present a
  4 18 potential conflict of interest.
  4 19    Sec. 3.    1  8 context otherwise requires, the words and phrases used in this
  1  9 chapter shall have the same meaning as the words and phrases
  1 10 used in chapter 490, including but not limited to the words
  1 11 and phrases used in section 490.140.  In addition, all of the
  1 12 following shall apply:
  1 13    1.  "Benefit corporation" means a business corporation, if
  1 14 all of the following apply:
  1 15    a.  It has elected to become subject to this chapter.
  1 16    b.  Its status as a benefit corporation has not been
  1 17 terminated.
  1 18    2.  "Benefit director" means a director designated as
  1 19 the benefit director of a benefit corporation under section
  1 20 490B.302.
  1 21    3.  "Benefit enforcement proceeding" means a claim or action
  1 22 relating to any of the following:
  1 23    a.  The failure of a benefit corporation to pursue or create
  1 24 general public benefit or a specific public benefit set forth
  1 25 in its articles of incorporation.

  1 27 conduct provided under this chapter.

  2 28 or consent, the satisfaction of all the following conditions:

  2 30 in the entity that are entitled to receive a distribution of
  2 31 any kind from the entity are entitled to vote on or consent to
  2 32 the action regardless of any otherwise applicable limitation on
  2 33 the voting or consent rights of any class or series.
  2 34    (2)  The action  is approved by vote or consent of the
  2 35 holders described in subparagraph (1) entitled to cast at least
  3  1 two=thirds of the votes or consents that all of those holders
  3  2 are entitled to cast on the action.
  3  3    10.  "Specific public benefit" means any of the following:
  3  4    a.  Providing low=income or underserved individuals or
  3  5 communities with beneficial products or services.
  3  6    b.  Promoting economic opportunity for individuals or
  3  7 communities beyond the creation of jobs in the normal course
  3  8 of business.
  3  9    c.  Protecting or restoring the environment.
  3 10    d.  Improving human health.
  3 11    e.  Promoting the arts, sciences, or advancement of
  3 12 knowledge.
  3 13    f.  Increasing  the flow of capital to entities with a purpose
  3 14 to benefit society or the environment.
  3 15    g.  Conferring any other particular benefit on society or the
  3 16 environment.
  3 17    11.  "Subsidiary" means, in relation to a person, an entity
  3 18 in which the person holds beneficially or of record  fifty
  3 19 percent  or more of the outstanding equity interests.
  3 20    12.  "Third=party standard" means a recognized standard
  3 21 for defining, reporting, and assessing corporate social or

  3 33 develop the standard, including a reasonable public comment
  3 34 period.
  3 35    d.  Transparent because the following information is made
  4  1 publicly available:
  4  2    (1)  A description of the standard that includes all of the
  4  3 following:
  4  4    (a)  Criteria considered when measuring the overall social
  4  5 or environmental performance of a business corporation.
  4  6    (b)  The relative weightings, if any, of  the criteria
  4  7 described in subparagraph division (a).
  4  8    (2)  A description of the development and revision of the
  4  9 standard which includes all of the following:
  4 10    (a)  The identity of the directors, officers, material
  4 11 owners, and the governing body of the entity that developed and
  4 12 controls revisions to the standard.
  4 13    (b)  The process by which revisions to the standard and
  4 14 changes to the membership of the governing body are made.
  4 15    (c)  An accounting of the revenue and sources of financial
  4 16 support for the entity, with sufficient detail to disclose any
  4 17 relationship that could reasonably be considered to present a
  4 18 potential conflict of interest.
  4 19    Sec. 3.    1 11 and phrases used in section 490.140.  In addition, all of the
  1 12 following shall apply:
  1 13    1.  "Benefit corporation" means a business corporation, if
  1 14 all of the following apply:
  1 15    a.  It has elected to become subject to this chapter.
  1 16    b.  Its status as a benefit corporation has not been
  1 17 terminated.
  1 18    2.  "Benefit director" means a director designated as
  1 19 the benefit director of a benefit corporation under section
  1 20 490B.302.
  1 21    3.  "Benefit enforcement proceeding" means a claim or action
  1 22 relating to any of the following:
  1 23    a.  The failure of a benefit corporation to pursue or create
  1 24 general public benefit or a specific public benefit set forth
  1 25 in its articles of incorporation.
  1 26    b.  A violation of any obligation, duty, or standard of
  1 27 conduct provided under this chapter.
  1 28    4.  "Benefit officer" means an individual designated as
  1 29 the benefit officer of a benefit corporation under section
  1 30 490B.304.
  1 31    5.  "Business corporation" means a corporation formed as a
  1 32 domestic corporation under chapter 490.
  1 33    6.  "Entity" means a person formed under the laws of
  1 34 this state including but not limited to a limited liability
  1 35 company under chapter 489; a corporation under chapter 490;
  2  1 a nonprofit corporation under chapter 504; a partnership,
  2  2 limited partnership, limited liability partnership, or limited
  2  3 liability limited partnership under chapter 486A or 488; or a
  2  4 cooperative association or other cooperative organized under
  2  5 chapter 497, 498, 499, 501, or 501A.
  2  6    7.  "General public benefit" means a material positive impact
  2  7 on society and the environment, taken as a whole, assessed
  2  8 against a third=party standard, which results from the business
  2  9 and operations of a benefit corporation.
  2 10    8.  "Independent" means having no material relationship
  2 11 with a benefit corporation or a subsidiary of the benefit
  2 12 corporation as provided in section 490B.304A.
  2 13    9.  "Minimum status vote" means any of the following:
  2 14    a.  In the case of a business corporation, in addition to any
  2 15 other required approval or vote required under chapter 490, the
  2 16 satisfaction of all of the following conditions:
  2 17    (1)  The shareholders of every class or series are
  2 18 entitled to vote as a separate voting group on the corporate
  2 19 action regardless of a limitation stated in the articles of
  2 20 incorporation or bylaws regarding the voting rights of any
  2 21 class or series.
  2 22    (2)  The corporate action is approved by vote of the
  2 23 shareholders of each class or series entitled to cast at least
  2 24 two=thirds of the votes that all shareholders of the class or
  2 25 series are entitled to cast on the action.
  2 26    b.  In the case of an entity other than a business
  2 27 corporation, in addition to any other required approval, vote,
  2 28 or consent, the satisfaction of all the following conditions:
  2 29    (1)  The holders of every class or series of equity interest
  2 30 in the entity that are entitled to receive a distribution of
  2 31 any kind from the entity are entitled to vote on or consent to
  2 32 the action regardless of any otherwise applicable limitation on
  2 33 the voting or consent rights of any class or series.
  2 34    (2)  The action  is approved by vote or consent of the
  2 35 holders described in subparagraph (1) entitled to cast at least
  3  1 two=thirds of the votes or consents that all of those holders
  3  2 are entitled to cast on the action.
  3  3    10.  "Specific public benefit" means any of the following:
  3  4    a.  Providing low=income or underserved individuals or
  3  5 communities with beneficial products or services.
  3  6    b.  Promoting economic opportunity for individuals or
  3  7 communities beyond the creation of jobs in the normal course
  3  8 of business.
  3  9    c.  Protecting or restoring the environment.
  3 10    d.  Improving human health.
  3 11    e.  Promoting the arts, sciences, or advancement of
  3 12 knowledge.
  3 13    f.  Increasing  the flow of capital to entities with a purpose
  3 14 to benefit society or the environment.
  3 15    g.  Conferring any other particular benefit on society or the
  3 16 environment.
  3 17    11.  "Subsidiary" means, in relation to a person, an entity
  3 18 in which the person holds beneficially or of record  fifty
  3 19 percent  or more of the outstanding equity interests.
  3 20    12.  "Third=party standard" means a recognized standard
  3 21 for defining, reporting, and assessing corporate social or
  3 22 environmental performance that is all of the following:
  3 23    a.  Comprehensive because the standard assesses the effect of
  3 24 the business and its operations upon the interests listed in
  3 25 section 490B.301, subsection 1, paragraphs "b" through "e".
  3 26    b.  Developed by an entity that is not controlled by the
  3 27 benefit corporation.
  3 28    c.  Credible because the standard is developed by an entity
  3 29 that meets all of the following conditions:
  3 30    (1)  Has access to necessary expertise to assess overall
  3 31 corporate social or environmental performance.
  3 32    (2)  Uses a balanced multiple stakeholder approach to
  3 33 develop the standard, including a reasonable public comment
  3 34 period.
  3 35    d.  Transparent because the following information is made
  4  1 publicly available:
  4  2    (1)  A description of the standard that includes all of the
  4  3 following:
  4  4    (a)  Criteria considered when measuring the overall social
  4  5 or environmental performance of a business corporation.
  4  6    (b)  The relative weightings, if any, of  the criteria
  4  7 described in subparagraph division (a).
  4  8    (2)  A description of the development and revision of the
  4  9 standard which includes all of the following:
  4 10    (a)  The identity of the directors, officers, material
  4 11 owners, and the governing body of the entity that developed and
  4 12 controls revisions to the standard.
  4 13    (b)  The process by which revisions to the standard and
  4 14 changes to the membership of the governing body are made.
  4 15    (c)  An accounting of the revenue and sources of financial
  4 16 support for the entity, with sufficient detail to disclose any
  4 17 relationship that could reasonably be considered to present a
  4 18 potential conflict of interest.

  2 22    (2)  The corporate action is approved by vote of the
  2 23 shareholders of each class or series entitled to cast at least
  2 24 two=thirds of the votes that all shareholders of the class or
  2 25 series are entitled to cast on the action.
  2 26    b.  In the case of an entity other than a business
  2 27 corporation, in addition to any other required approval, vote,
  2 28 or consent, the satisfaction of all the following conditions:
  2 29    (1)  The holders of every class or series of equity interest
  2 30 in the entity that are entitled to receive a distribution of
  2 31 any kind from the entity are entitled to vote on or consent to
  2 32 the action regardless of any otherwise applicable limitation on
  2 33 the voting or consent rights of any class or series.
  2 34    (2)  The action  is approved by vote or consent of the
  2 35 holders described in subparagraph (1) entitled to cast at least
  3  1 two=thirds of the votes or consents that all of those holders
  3  2 are entitled to cast on the action.
  3  3    10.  "Specific public benefit" means any of the following:
  3  4    a.  Providing low=income or underserved individuals or
  3  5 communities with beneficial products or services.
  3  6    b.  Promoting economic opportunity for individuals or
  3  7 communities beyond the creation of jobs in the normal course
  3  8 of business.
  3  9    c.  Protecting or restoring the environment.
  3 10    d.  Improving human health.
  3 11    e.  Promoting the arts, sciences, or advancement of
  3 12 knowledge.
  3 13    f.  Increasing  the flow of capital to entities with a purpose
  3 14 to benefit society or the environment.
  3 15    g.  Conferring any other particular benefit on society or the
  3 16 environment.
  3 17    11.  "Subsidiary" means, in relation to a person, an entity
  3 18 in which the person holds beneficially or of record  fifty
  3 19 percent  or more of the outstanding equity interests.
  3 20    12.  "Third=party standard" means a recognized standard
  3 21 for defining, reporting, and assessing corporate social or
  3 22 environmental performance that is all of the following:
  3 23    a.  Comprehensive because the standard assesses the effect of
  3 24 the business and its operations upon the interests listed in
  3 25 section 490B.301, subsection 1, paragraphs "b" through "e".
  3 26    b.  Developed by an entity that is not controlled by the
  3 27 benefit corporation.
  3 28    c.  Credible because the standard is developed by an entity
  3 29 that meets all of the following conditions:
  3 30    (1)  Has access to necessary expertise to assess overall
  3 31 corporate social or environmental performance.
  3 32    (2)  Uses a balanced multiple stakeholder approach to
  3 33 develop the standard, including a reasonable public comment
  3 34 period.
  3 35    d.  Transparent because the following information is made
  4  1 publicly available:
  4  2    (1)  A description of the standard that includes all of the
  4  3 following:
  4  4    (a)  Criteria considered when measuring the overall social
  4  5 or environmental performance of a business corporation.
  4  6    (b)  The relative weightings, if any, of  the criteria
  4  7 described in subparagraph division (a).
  4  8    (2)  A description of the development and revision of the
  4  9 standard which includes all of the following:
  4 10    (a)  The identity of the directors, officers, material
  4 11 owners, and the governing body of the entity that developed and
  4 12 controls revisions to the standard.
  4 13    (b)  The process by which revisions to the standard and
  4 14 changes to the membership of the governing body are made.
  4 15    (c)  An accounting of the revenue and sources of financial
  4 16 support for the entity, with sufficient detail to disclose any
  4 17 relationship that could reasonably be considered to present a
  4 18 potential conflict of interest.
  4 19    Sec. 3.    1 16    b.  Its status as a benefit corporation has not been

  1 35 company under chapter 489; a corporation under chapter 490;
  2  1 a nonprofit corporation under chapter 504; a partnership,
  2  2 limited partnership, limited liability partnership, or limited
  2  3 liability limited partnership under chapter 486A or 488; or a
  2  4 cooperative association or other cooperative organized under
  2  5 chapter 497, 498, 499, 501, or 501A.
  2  6    7.  "General public benefit" means a material positive impact
  2  7 on society and the environment, taken as a whole, assessed
  2  8 against a third=party standard, which results from the business
  2  9 and operations of a benefit corporation.
  2 10    8.  "Independent" means having no material relationship
  2 11 with a benefit corporation or a subsidiary of the benefit
  2 12 corporation as provided in section 490B.304A.
  2 13    9.  "Minimum status vote" means any of the following:
  2 14    a.  In the case of a business corporation, in addition to any
  2 15 other required approval or vote required under chapter 490, the
  2 16 satisfaction of all of the following conditions:
  2 17    (1)  The shareholders of every class or series are
  2 18 entitled to vote as a separate voting group on the corporate
  2 19 action regardless of a limitation stated in the articles of
  2 20 incorporation or bylaws regarding the voting rights of any
  2 21 class or series.
  2 22    (2)  The corporate action is approved by vote of the
  2 23 shareholders of each class or series entitled to cast at least
  2 24 two=thirds of the votes that all shareholders of the class or
  2 25 series are entitled to cast on the action.
  2 26    b.  In the case of an entity other than a business
  2 27 corporation, in addition to any other required approval, vote,
  2 28 or consent, the satisfaction of all the following conditions:
  2 29    (1)  The holders of every class or series of equity interest
  2 30 in the entity that are entitled to receive a distribution of
  2 31 any kind from the entity are entitled to vote on or consent to
  2 32 the action regardless of any otherwise applicable limitation on
  2 33 the voting or consent rights of any class or series.
  2 34    (2)  The action  is approved by vote or consent of the
  2 35 holders described in subparagraph (1) entitled to cast at least
  3  1 two=thirds of the votes or consents that all of those holders
  3  2 are entitled to cast on the action.
  3  3    10.  "Specific public benefit" means any of the following:
  3  4    a.  Providing low=income or underserved individuals or
  3  5 communities with beneficial products or services.
  3  6    b.  Promoting economic opportunity for individuals or
  3  7 communities beyond the creation of jobs in the normal course
  3  8 of business.
  3  9    c.  Protecting or restoring the environment.
  3 10    d.  Improving human health.
  3 11    e.  Promoting the arts, sciences, or advancement of
  3 12 knowledge.
  3 13    f.  Increasing  the flow of capital to entities with a purpose
  3 14 to benefit society or the environment.
  3 15    g.  Conferring any other particular benefit on society or the
  3 16 environment.
  3 17    11.  "Subsidiary" means, in relation to a person, an entity
  3 18 in which the person holds beneficially or of record  fifty
  3 19 percent  or more of the outstanding equity interests.
  3 20    12.  "Third=party standard" means a recognized standard
  3 21 for defining, reporting, and assessing corporate social or
  3 22 environmental performance that is all of the following:
  3 23    a.  Comprehensive because the standard assesses the effect of
  3 24 the business and its operations upon the interests listed in
  3 25 section 490B.301, subsection 1, paragraphs "b" through "e".
  3 26    b.  Developed by an entity that is not controlled by the
  3 27 benefit corporation.
  3 28    c.  Credible because the standard is developed by an entity
  3 29 that meets all of the following conditions:
  3 30    (1)  Has access to necessary expertise to assess overall
  3 31 corporate social or environmental performance.
  3 32    (2)  Uses a balanced multiple stakeholder approach to
  3 33 develop the standard, including a reasonable public comment
  3 34 period.
  3 35    d.  Transparent because the following information is made
  4  1 publicly available:
  4  2    (1)  A description of the standard that includes all of the
  4  3 following:
  4  4    (a)  Criteria considered when measuring the overall social
  4  5 or environmental performance of a business corporation.
  4  6    (b)  The relative weightings, if any, of  the criteria
  4  7 described in subparagraph division (a).
  4  8    (2)  A description of the development and revision of the
  4  9 standard which includes all of the following:
  4 10    (a)  The identity of the directors, officers, material
  4 11 owners, and the governing body of the entity that developed and
  4 12 controls revisions to the standard.
  4 13    (b)  The process by which revisions to the standard and
  4 14 changes to the membership of the governing body are made.
  4 15    (c)  An accounting of the revenue and sources of financial
  4 16 support for the entity, with sufficient detail to disclose any
  4 17 relationship that could reasonably be considered to present a
  4 18 potential conflict of interest.
  4 19    Sec. 3.    1 21    3.  "Benefit enforcement proceeding" means a claim or action

  1 24 general public benefit or a specific public benefit set forth
  1 25 in its articles of incorporation.
  1 26    b.  A violation of any obligation, duty, or standard of
  1 27 conduct provided under this chapter.

  1 35 company under chapter 489; a corporation under chapter 490;
  2  1 a nonprofit corporation under chapter 504; a partnership,
  2  2 limited partnership, limited liability partnership, or limited
  2  3 liability limited partnership under chapter 486A or 488; or a
  2  4 cooperative association or other cooperative organized under
  2  5 chapter 497, 498, 499, 501, or 501A.
  2  6    7.  "General public benefit" means a material positive impact
  2  7 on society and the environment, taken as a whole, assessed
  2  8 against a third=party standard, which results from the business
  2  9 and operations of a benefit corporation.
  2 10    8.  "Independent" means having no material relationship
  2 11 with a benefit corporation or a subsidiary of the benefit
  2 12 corporation as provided in section 490B.304A.
  2 13    9.  "Minimum status vote" means any of the following:
  2 14    a.  In the case of a business corporation, in addition to any
  2 15 other required approval or vote required under chapter 490, the
  2 16 satisfaction of all of the following conditions:
  2 17    (1)  The shareholders of every class or series are
  2 18 entitled to vote as a separate voting group on the corporate
  2 19 action regardless of a limitation stated in the articles of
  2 20 incorporation or bylaws regarding the voting rights of any
  2 21 class or series.
  2 22    (2)  The corporate action is approved by vote of the
  2 23 shareholders of each class or series entitled to cast at least
  2 24 two=thirds of the votes that all shareholders of the class or
  2 25 series are entitled to cast on the action.
  2 26    b.  In the case of an entity other than a business
  2 27 corporation, in addition to any other required approval, vote,
  2 28 or consent, the satisfaction of all the following conditions:
  2 29    (1)  The holders of every class or series of equity interest
  2 30 in the entity that are entitled to receive a distribution of
  2 31 any kind from the entity are entitled to vote on or consent to
  2 32 the action regardless of any otherwise applicable limitation on
  2 33 the voting or consent rights of any class or series.
  2 34    (2)  The action  is approved by vote or consent of the
  2 35 holders described in subparagraph (1) entitled to cast at least
  3  1 two=thirds of the votes or consents that all of those holders
  3  2 are entitled to cast on the action.
  3  3    10.  "Specific public benefit" means any of the following:
  3  4    a.  Providing low=income or underserved individuals or
  3  5 communities with beneficial products or services.
  3  6    b.  Promoting economic opportunity for individuals or
  3  7 communities beyond the creation of jobs in the normal course
  3  8 of business.
  3  9    c.  Protecting or restoring the environment.
  3 10    d.  Improving human health.
  3 11    e.  Promoting the arts, sciences, or advancement of
  3 12 knowledge.
  3 13    f.  Increasing  the flow of capital to entities with a purpose
  3 14 to benefit society or the environment.
  3 15    g.  Conferring any other particular benefit on society or the
  3 16 environment.
  3 17    11.  "Subsidiary" means, in relation to a person, an entity
  3 18 in which the person holds beneficially or of record  fifty
  3 19 percent  or more of the outstanding equity interests.
  3 20    12.  "Third=party standard" means a recognized standard
  3 21 for defining, reporting, and assessing corporate social or
  3 22 environmental performance that is all of the following:
  3 23    a.  Comprehensive because the standard assesses the effect of
  3 24 the business and its operations upon the interests listed in
  3 25 section 490B.301, subsection 1, paragraphs "b" through "e".
  3 26    b.  Developed by an entity that is not controlled by the
  3 27 benefit corporation.
  3 28    c.  Credible because the standard is developed by an entity
  3 29 that meets all of the following conditions:
  3 30    (1)  Has access to necessary expertise to assess overall
  3 31 corporate social or environmental performance.
  3 32    (2)  Uses a balanced multiple stakeholder approach to
  3 33 develop the standard, including a reasonable public comment
  3 34 period.
  3 35    d.  Transparent because the following information is made
  4  1 publicly available:
  4  2    (1)  A description of the standard that includes all of the
  4  3 following:
  4  4    (a)  Criteria considered when measuring the overall social
  4  5 or environmental performance of a business corporation.
  4  6    (b)  The relative weightings, if any, of  the criteria
  4  7 described in subparagraph division (a).
  4  8    (2)  A description of the development and revision of the
  4  9 standard which includes all of the following:
  4 10    (a)  The identity of the directors, officers, material
  4 11 owners, and the governing body of the entity that developed and
  4 12 controls revisions to the standard.
  4 13    (b)  The process by which revisions to the standard and
  4 14 changes to the membership of the governing body are made.
  4 15    (c)  An accounting of the revenue and sources of financial
  4 16 support for the entity, with sufficient detail to disclose any
  4 17 relationship that could reasonably be considered to present a
  4 18 potential conflict of interest.
  4 19    Sec. 3.    1 26    b.  A violation of any obligation, duty, or standard of

  2 23 shareholders of each class or series entitled to cast at least
  2 24 two=thirds of the votes that all shareholders of the class or
  2 25 series are entitled to cast on the action.
  2 26    b.  In the case of an entity other than a business
  2 27 corporation, in addition to any other required approval, vote,
  2 28 or consent, the satisfaction of all the following conditions:
  2 29    (1)  The holders of every class or series of equity interest
  2 30 in the entity that are entitled to receive a distribution of
  2 31 any kind from the entity are entitled to vote on or consent to
  2 32 the action regardless of any otherwise applicable limitation on
  2 33 the voting or consent rights of any class or series.
  2 34    (2)  The action  is approved by vote or consent of the
  2 35 holders described in subparagraph (1) entitled to cast at least
  3  1 two=thirds of the votes or consents that all of those holders
  3  2 are entitled to cast on the action.
  3  3    10.  "Specific public benefit" means any of the following:
  3  4    a.  Providing low=income or underserved individuals or
  3  5 communities with beneficial products or services.
  3  6    b.  Promoting economic opportunity for individuals or
  3  7 communities beyond the creation of jobs in the normal course
  3  8 of business.
  3  9    c.  Protecting or restoring the environment.
  3 10    d.  Improving human health.
  3 11    e.  Promoting the arts, sciences, or advancement of
  3 12 knowledge.
  3 13    f.  Increasing  the flow of capital to entities with a purpose
  3 14 to benefit society or the environment.
  3 15    g.  Conferring any other particular benefit on society or the
  3 16 environment.
  3 17    11.  "Subsidiary" means, in relation to a person, an entity
  3 18 in which the person holds beneficially or of record  fifty
  3 19 percent  or more of the outstanding equity interests.
  3 20    12.  "Third=party standard" means a recognized standard
  3 21 for defining, reporting, and assessing corporate social or
  3 22 environmental performance that is all of the following:
  3 23    a.  Comprehensive because the standard assesses the effect of
  3 24 the business and its operations upon the interests listed in
  3 25 section 490B.301, subsection 1, paragraphs "b" through "e".
  3 26    b.  Developed by an entity that is not controlled by the
  3 27 benefit corporation.
  3 28    c.  Credible because the standard is developed by an entity
  3 29 that meets all of the following conditions:
  3 30    (1)  Has access to necessary expertise to assess overall
  3 31 corporate social or environmental performance.
  3 32    (2)  Uses a balanced multiple stakeholder approach to
  3 33 develop the standard, including a reasonable public comment
  3 34 period.
  3 35    d.  Transparent because the following information is made
  4  1 publicly available:
  4  2    (1)  A description of the standard that includes all of the
  4  3 following:
  4  4    (a)  Criteria considered when measuring the overall social
  4  5 or environmental performance of a business corporation.
  4  6    (b)  The relative weightings, if any, of  the criteria
  4  7 described in subparagraph division (a).
  4  8    (2)  A description of the development and revision of the
  4  9 standard which includes all of the following:
  4 10    (a)  The identity of the directors, officers, material
  4 11 owners, and the governing body of the entity that developed and
  4 12 controls revisions to the standard.
  4 13    (b)  The process by which revisions to the standard and
  4 14 changes to the membership of the governing body are made.
  4 15    (c)  An accounting of the revenue and sources of financial
  4 16 support for the entity, with sufficient detail to disclose any
  4 17 relationship that could reasonably be considered to present a
  4 18 potential conflict of interest.
  4 19    Sec. 3.    1 31    5.  "Business corporation" means a corporation formed as a
  1 32 domestic corporation under chapter 490.
  1 33    6.  "Entity" means a person formed under the laws of
  1 34 this state including but not limited to a limited liability
  1 35 company under chapter 489; a corporation under chapter 490;
  2  1 a nonprofit corporation under chapter 504; a partnership,
  2  2 limited partnership, limited liability partnership, or limited
  2  3 liability limited partnership under chapter 486A or 488; or a
  2  4 cooperative association or other cooperative organized under
  2  5 chapter 497, 498, 499, 501, or 501A.
  2  6    7.  "General public benefit" means a material positive impact
  2  7 on society and the environment, taken as a whole, assessed
  2  8 against a third=party standard, which results from the business
  2  9 and operations of a benefit corporation.
  2 10    8.  "Independent" means having no material relationship
  2 11 with a benefit corporation or a subsidiary of the benefit
  2 12 corporation as provided in section 490B.304A.
  2 13    9.  "Minimum status vote" means any of the following:
  2 14    a.  In the case of a business corporation, in addition to any
  2 15 other required approval or vote required under chapter 490, the
  2 16 satisfaction of all of the following conditions:
  2 17    (1)  The shareholders of every class or series are
  2 18 entitled to vote as a separate voting group on the corporate
  2 19 action regardless of a limitation stated in the articles of
  2 20 incorporation or bylaws regarding the voting rights of any
  2 21 class or series.
  2 22    (2)  The corporate action is approved by vote of the
  2 23 shareholders of each class or series entitled to cast at least
  2 24 two=thirds of the votes that all shareholders of the class or
  2 25 series are entitled to cast on the action.
  2 26    b.  In the case of an entity other than a business

  3 35    d.  Transparent because the following information is made
  4  1 publicly available:
  4  2    (1)  A description of the standard that includes all of the
  4  3 following:
  4  4    (a)  Criteria considered when measuring the overall social
  4  5 or environmental performance of a business corporation.
  4  6    (b)  The relative weightings, if any, of  the criteria
  4  7 described in subparagraph division (a).
  4  8    (2)  A description of the development and revision of the
  4  9 standard which includes all of the following:
  4 10    (a)  The identity of the directors, officers, material
  4 11 owners, and the governing body of the entity that developed and
  4 12 controls revisions to the standard.
  4 13    (b)  The process by which revisions to the standard and
  4 14 changes to the membership of the governing body are made.
  4 15    (c)  An accounting of the revenue and sources of financial
  4 16 support for the entity, with sufficient detail to disclose any
  4 17 relationship that could reasonably be considered to present a
  4 18 potential conflict of interest.
  4 19    Sec. 3.    2  1 a nonprofit corporation under chapter 504; a partnership,
  2  2 limited partnership, limited liability partnership, or limited
  2  3 liability limited partnership under chapter 486A or 488; or a
  2  4 cooperative association or other cooperative organized under
  2  5 chapter 497, 498, 499, 501, or 501A.
  2  6    7.  "General public benefit" means a material positive impact
  2  7 on society and the environment, taken as a whole, assessed
  2  8 against a third=party standard, which results from the business
  2  9 and operations of a benefit corporation.
  2 10    8.  "Independent" means having no material relationship
  2 11 with a benefit corporation or a subsidiary of the benefit
  2 12 corporation as provided in section 490B.304A.
  2 13    9.  "Minimum status vote" means any of the following:
  2 14    a.  In the case of a business corporation, in addition to any
  2 15 other required approval or vote required under chapter 490, the
  2 16 satisfaction of all of the following conditions:
  2 17    (1)  The shareholders of every class or series are
  2 18 entitled to vote as a separate voting group on the corporate
  2 19 action regardless of a limitation stated in the articles of
  2 20 incorporation or bylaws regarding the voting rights of any
  2 21 class or series.
  2 22    (2)  The corporate action is approved by vote of the
  2 23 shareholders of each class or series entitled to cast at least
  2 24 two=thirds of the votes that all shareholders of the class or
  2 25 series are entitled to cast on the action.
  2 26    b.  In the case of an entity other than a business
  2 27 corporation, in addition to any other required approval, vote,
  2 28 or consent, the satisfaction of all the following conditions:
  2 29    (1)  The holders of every class or series of equity interest
  2 30 in the entity that are entitled to receive a distribution of
  2 31 any kind from the entity are entitled to vote on or consent to
  2 32 the action regardless of any otherwise applicable limitation on
  2 33 the voting or consent rights of any class or series.
  2 34    (2)  The action  is approved by vote or consent of the
  2 35 holders described in subparagraph (1) entitled to cast at least
  3  1 two=thirds of the votes or consents that all of those holders
  3  2 are entitled to cast on the action.
  3  3    10.  "Specific public benefit" means any of the following:
  3  4    a.  Providing low=income or underserved individuals or
  3  5 communities with beneficial products or services.
  3  6    b.  Promoting economic opportunity for individuals or
  3  7 communities beyond the creation of jobs in the normal course
  3  8 of business.
  3  9    c.  Protecting or restoring the environment.
  3 10    d.  Improving human health.
  3 11    e.  Promoting the arts, sciences, or advancement of
  3 12 knowledge.
  3 13    f.  Increasing  the flow of capital to entities with a purpose
  3 14 to benefit society or the environment.
  3 15    g.  Conferring any other particular benefit on society or the
  3 16 environment.
  3 17    11.  "Subsidiary" means, in relation to a person, an entity
  3 18 in which the person holds beneficially or of record  fifty
  3 19 percent  or more of the outstanding equity interests.
  3 20    12.  "Third=party standard" means a recognized standard
  3 21 for defining, reporting, and assessing corporate social or
  3 22 environmental performance that is all of the following:
  3 23    a.  Comprehensive because the standard assesses the effect of
  3 24 the business and its operations upon the interests listed in
  3 25 section 490B.301, subsection 1, paragraphs "b" through "e".
  3 26    b.  Developed by an entity that is not controlled by the
  3 27 benefit corporation.
  3 28    c.  Credible because the standard is developed by an entity
  3 29 that meets all of the following conditions:
  3 30    (1)  Has access to necessary expertise to assess overall
  3 31 corporate social or environmental performance.
  3 32    (2)  Uses a balanced multiple stakeholder approach to
  3 33 develop the standard, including a reasonable public comment
  3 34 period.
  3 35    d.  Transparent because the following information is made
  4  1 publicly available:

  3 23    a.  Comprehensive because the standard assesses the effect of
  3 24 the business and its operations upon the interests listed in
  3 25 section 490B.301, subsection 1, paragraphs "b" through "e".
  3 26    b.  Developed by an entity that is not controlled by the
  3 27 benefit corporation.
  3 28    c.  Credible because the standard is developed by an entity
  3 29 that meets all of the following conditions:
  3 30    (1)  Has access to necessary expertise to assess overall
  3 31 corporate social or environmental performance.
  3 32    (2)  Uses a balanced multiple stakeholder approach to
  3 33 develop the standard, including a reasonable public comment
  3 34 period.
  3 35    d.  Transparent because the following information is made
  4  1 publicly available:
  4  2    (1)  A description of the standard that includes all of the
  4  3 following:
  4  4    (a)  Criteria considered when measuring the overall social
  4  5 or environmental performance of a business corporation.
  4  6    (b)  The relative weightings, if any, of  the criteria
  4  7 described in subparagraph division (a).
  4  8    (2)  A description of the development and revision of the
  4  9 standard which includes all of the following:
  4 10    (a)  The identity of the directors, officers, material
  4 11 owners, and the governing body of the entity that developed and
  4 12 controls revisions to the standard.
  4 13    (b)  The process by which revisions to the standard and
  4 14 changes to the membership of the governing body are made.
  4 15    (c)  An accounting of the revenue and sources of financial
  4 16 support for the entity, with sufficient detail to disclose any
  4 17 relationship that could reasonably be considered to present a
  4 18 potential conflict of interest.
  4 19    Sec. 3.    2  7 on society and the environment, taken as a whole, assessed
  2  8 against a third=party standard, which results from the business
  2  9 and operations of a benefit corporation.
  2 10    8.  "Independent" means having no material relationship
  2 11 with a benefit corporation or a subsidiary of the benefit
  2 12 corporation as provided in section 490B.304A.
  2 13    9.  "Minimum status vote" means any of the following:
  2 14    a.  In the case of a business corporation, in addition to any
  2 15 other required approval or vote required under chapter 490, the
  2 16 satisfaction of all of the following conditions:
  2 17    (1)  The shareholders of every class or series are
  2 18 entitled to vote as a separate voting group on the corporate
  2 19 action regardless of a limitation stated in the articles of
  2 20 incorporation or bylaws regarding the voting rights of any
  2 21 class or series.
  2 22    (2)  The corporate action is approved by vote of the
  2 23 shareholders of each class or series entitled to cast at least
  2 24 two=thirds of the votes that all shareholders of the class or
  2 25 series are entitled to cast on the action.
  2 26    b.  In the case of an entity other than a business
  2 27 corporation, in addition to any other required approval, vote,
  2 28 or consent, the satisfaction of all the following conditions:
  2 29    (1)  The holders of every class or series of equity interest
  2 30 in the entity that are entitled to receive a distribution of
  2 31 any kind from the entity are entitled to vote on or consent to
  2 32 the action regardless of any otherwise applicable limitation on
  2 33 the voting or consent rights of any class or series.
  2 34    (2)  The action  is approved by vote or consent of the
  2 35 holders described in subparagraph (1) entitled to cast at least
  3  1 two=thirds of the votes or consents that all of those holders
  3  2 are entitled to cast on the action.
  3  3    10.  "Specific public benefit" means any of the following:
  3  4    a.  Providing low=income or underserved individuals or
  3  5 communities with beneficial products or services.
  3  6    b.  Promoting economic opportunity for individuals or
  3  7 communities beyond the creation of jobs in the normal course
  3  8 of business.
  3  9    c.  Protecting or restoring the environment.
  3 10    d.  Improving human health.
  3 11    e.  Promoting the arts, sciences, or advancement of
  3 12 knowledge.
  3 13    f.  Increasing  the flow of capital to entities with a purpose
  3 14 to benefit society or the environment.
  3 15    g.  Conferring any other particular benefit on society or the
  3 16 environment.
  3 17    11.  "Subsidiary" means, in relation to a person, an entity
  3 18 in which the person holds beneficially or of record  fifty
  3 19 percent  or more of the outstanding equity interests.

  4 15    (c)  An accounting of the revenue and sources of financial
  4 16 support for the entity, with sufficient detail to disclose any
  4 17 relationship that could reasonably be considered to present a
  4 18 potential conflict of interest.
  4 19    Sec. 3.    2 13    9.  "Minimum status vote" means any of the following:
  2 14    a.  In the case of a business corporation, in addition to any
  2 15 other required approval or vote required under chapter 490, the
  2 16 satisfaction of all of the following conditions:
  2 17    (1)  The shareholders of every class or series are
  2 18 entitled to vote as a separate voting group on the corporate
  2 19 action regardless of a limitation stated in the articles of
  2 20 incorporation or bylaws regarding the voting rights of any
  2 21 class or series.
  2 22    (2)  The corporate action is approved by vote of the
  2 23 shareholders of each class or series entitled to cast at least
  2 24 two=thirds of the votes that all shareholders of the class or
  2 25 series are entitled to cast on the action.
  2 26    b.  In the case of an entity other than a business
  2 27 corporation, in addition to any other required approval, vote,
  2 28 or consent, the satisfaction of all the following conditions:
  2 29    (1)  The holders of every class or series of equity interest
  2 30 in the entity that are entitled to receive a distribution of
  2 31 any kind from the entity are entitled to vote on or consent to
  2 32 the action regardless of any otherwise applicable limitation on
  2 33 the voting or consent rights of any class or series.
  2 34    (2)  The action  is approved by vote or consent of the
  2 35 holders described in subparagraph (1) entitled to cast at least
  3  1 two=thirds of the votes or consents that all of those holders
  3  2 are entitled to cast on the action.
  3  3    10.  "Specific public benefit" means any of the following:
  3  4    a.  Providing low=income or underserved individuals or
  3  5 communities with beneficial products or services.
  3  6    b.  Promoting economic opportunity for individuals or
  3  7 communities beyond the creation of jobs in the normal course
  3  8 of business.
  3  9    c.  Protecting or restoring the environment.
  3 10    d.  Improving human health.
  3 11    e.  Promoting the arts, sciences, or advancement of
  3 12 knowledge.
  3 13    f.  Increasing  the flow of capital to entities with a purpose
  3 14 to benefit society or the environment.
  3 15    g.  Conferring any other particular benefit on society or the
  3 16 environment.
  3 17    11.  "Subsidiary" means, in relation to a person, an entity
  3 18 in which the person holds beneficially or of record  fifty
  3 19 percent  or more of the outstanding equity interests.
  3 20    12.  "Third=party standard" means a recognized standard
  3 21 for defining, reporting, and assessing corporate social or
  3 22 environmental performance that is all of the following:
  3 23    a.  Comprehensive because the standard assesses the effect of
  3 24 the business and its operations upon the interests listed in
  3 25 section 490B.301, subsection 1, paragraphs "b" through "e".
  3 26    b.  Developed by an entity that is not controlled by the
  3 27 benefit corporation.
  3 28    c.  Credible because the standard is developed by an entity
  3 29 that meets all of the following conditions:
  3 30    (1)  Has access to necessary expertise to assess overall
  3 31 corporate social or environmental performance.
  3 32    (2)  Uses a balanced multiple stakeholder approach to
  3 33 develop the standard, including a reasonable public comment
  3 34 period.
  3 35    d.  Transparent because the following information is made
  4  1 publicly available:
  4  2    (1)  A description of the standard that includes all of the
  4  3 following:
  4  4    (a)  Criteria considered when measuring the overall social
  4  5 or environmental performance of a business corporation.
  4  6    (b)  The relative weightings, if any, of  the criteria
  4  7 described in subparagraph division (a).
  4  8    (2)  A description of the development and revision of the
  4  9 standard which includes all of the following:
  4 10    (a)  The identity of the directors, officers, material
  4 11 owners, and the governing body of the entity that developed and
  4 12 controls revisions to the standard.
  4 13    (b)  The process by which revisions to the standard and
  4 14 changes to the membership of the governing body are made.
  4 15    (c)  An accounting of the revenue and sources of financial
  4 16 support for the entity, with sufficient detail to disclose any
  4 17 relationship that could reasonably be considered to present a
  4 18 potential conflict of interest.

  4 10    (a)  The identity of the directors, officers, material
  4 11 owners, and the governing body of the entity that developed and
  4 12 controls revisions to the standard.
  4 13    (b)  The process by which revisions to the standard and
  4 14 changes to the membership of the governing body are made.
  4 15    (c)  An accounting of the revenue and sources of financial
  4 16 support for the entity, with sufficient detail to disclose any
  4 17 relationship that could reasonably be considered to present a
  4 18 potential conflict of interest.
  4 19    Sec. 3.    2 20 incorporation or bylaws regarding the voting rights of any
  2 21 class or series.
  2 22    (2)  The corporate action is approved by vote of the
  2 23 shareholders of each class or series entitled to cast at least
  2 24 two=thirds of the votes that all shareholders of the class or
  2 25 series are entitled to cast on the action.
  2 26    b.  In the case of an entity other than a business
  2 27 corporation, in addition to any other required approval, vote,
  2 28 or consent, the satisfaction of all the following conditions:
  2 29    (1)  The holders of every class or series of equity interest
  2 30 in the entity that are entitled to receive a distribution of
  2 31 any kind from the entity are entitled to vote on or consent to
  2 32 the action regardless of any otherwise applicable limitation on
  2 33 the voting or consent rights of any class or series.
  2 34    (2)  The action  is approved by vote or consent of the
  2 35 holders described in subparagraph (1) entitled to cast at least
  3  1 two=thirds of the votes or consents that all of those holders
  3  2 are entitled to cast on the action.
  3  3    10.  "Specific public benefit" means any of the following:
  3  4    a.  Providing low=income or underserved individuals or
  3  5 communities with beneficial products or services.
  3  6    b.  Promoting economic opportunity for individuals or
  3  7 communities beyond the creation of jobs in the normal course
  3  8 of business.
  3  9    c.  Protecting or restoring the environment.
  3 10    d.  Improving human health.
  3 11    e.  Promoting the arts, sciences, or advancement of
  3 12 knowledge.
  3 13    f.  Increasing  the flow of capital to entities with a purpose
  3 14 to benefit society or the environment.
  3 15    g.  Conferring any other particular benefit on society or the
  3 16 environment.
  3 17    11.  "Subsidiary" means, in relation to a person, an entity
  3 18 in which the person holds beneficially or of record  fifty
  3 19 percent  or more of the outstanding equity interests.
  3 20    12.  "Third=party standard" means a recognized standard
  3 21 for defining, reporting, and assessing corporate social or
  3 22 environmental performance that is all of the following:
  3 23    a.  Comprehensive because the standard assesses the effect of
  3 24 the business and its operations upon the interests listed in
  3 25 section 490B.301, subsection 1, paragraphs "b" through "e".
  3 26    b.  Developed by an entity that is not controlled by the
  3 27 benefit corporation.
  3 28    c.  Credible because the standard is developed by an entity
  3 29 that meets all of the following conditions:
  3 30    (1)  Has access to necessary expertise to assess overall
  3 31 corporate social or environmental performance.
  3 32    (2)  Uses a balanced multiple stakeholder approach to
  3 33 develop the standard, including a reasonable public comment
  3 34 period.
  3 35    d.  Transparent because the following information is made
  4  1 publicly available:
  4  2    (1)  A description of the standard that includes all of the
  4  3 following:
  4  4    (a)  Criteria considered when measuring the overall social
  4  5 or environmental performance of a business corporation.
  4  6    (b)  The relative weightings, if any, of  the criteria
  4  7 described in subparagraph division (a).

  4  9 standard which includes all of the following:

  3 21 for defining, reporting, and assessing corporate social or
  3 22 environmental performance that is all of the following:
  3 23    a.  Comprehensive because the standard assesses the effect of
  3 24 the business and its operations upon the interests listed in
  3 25 section 490B.301, subsection 1, paragraphs "b" through "e".
  3 26    b.  Developed by an entity that is not controlled by the
  3 27 benefit corporation.
  3 28    c.  Credible because the standard is developed by an entity
  3 29 that meets all of the following conditions:
  3 30    (1)  Has access to necessary expertise to assess overall
  3 31 corporate social or environmental performance.
  3 32    (2)  Uses a balanced multiple stakeholder approach to
  3 33 develop the standard, including a reasonable public comment
  3 34 period.
  3 35    d.  Transparent because the following information is made
  4  1 publicly available:
  4  2    (1)  A description of the standard that includes all of the
  4  3 following:
  4  4    (a)  Criteria considered when measuring the overall social
  4  5 or environmental performance of a business corporation.

  4 11 owners, and the governing body of the entity that developed and
  4 12 controls revisions to the standard.
  4 13    (b)  The process by which revisions to the standard and
  4 14 changes to the membership of the governing body are made.
  4 15    (c)  An accounting of the revenue and sources of financial
  4 16 support for the entity, with sufficient detail to disclose any
  4 17 relationship that could reasonably be considered to present a
  4 18 potential conflict of interest.

  4 19    Sec. 3.    4 19    Sec. 3.    4 20 chapter.
  4 21    1.  This chapter applies to all benefit corporations.
  4 22    2.  The existence of a provision of this chapter shall not
  4 23 of itself create an implication that a contrary or different
  4 24 rule of law is applicable to a business corporation that is not
  4 25 a benefit corporation.  This chapter shall not affect a statute
  4 26 or rule of law that is applicable to a business corporation
  4 27 that is not a benefit corporation.
  4 28    3.  Chapter 490 shall be construed as part of this chapter
  4 29 and shall apply to benefit corporations, including but not
  4 30 limited to their formation or organization, reports, fees,
  4 31 authority, powers, rights, and the regulation and conduct of
  4 32 their affairs.
  4 33    4.  A benefit corporation may be subject simultaneously to
  4 34 this chapter and one or more other chapters of this title,
  4 35 including chapter 496C.  In such event, the provisions of
  5  1 this  chapter shall take precedence with respect to a benefit
  5  2 corporation.
  5  3    5.  A provision of the articles of incorporation or bylaws of
  5  4 a benefit corporation shall not limit, be inconsistent with, or
  5  5 supersede a provision of this chapter.

  5 14    1.  An existing business corporation may become a benefit
  5 15 corporation under this chapter by amending its articles of
  5 16 incorporation so that the articles contain, in addition to
  5 17 the requirements of chapter 490, division II, a statement
  5 18 that the corporation is a benefit corporation.  In order to
  5 19 be effective, the amendment must be adopted by at least the
  5 20 minimum status vote.
  5 21    2.  a.  An entity that is not a benefit corporation may
  5 22 become a benefit corporation pursuant to subsection 1 if all
  5 23 of the following apply:
  5 24    (1)  The entity is one of the following:
  5 25    (a)  A party to a merger or conversion.
  5 26    (b)  An exchanging entity in a share exchange.
  5 27    (2)  The surviving, new, or resulting entity in the merger,
  5 28 conversion, or share exchange is to be a benefit corporation.
  5 29    b.  In order to be effective, a plan of merger, conversion,
  5 30 or share exchange subject to paragraph "a" must be adopted by at
  5 31 least the minimum status vote.

  5 32    Sec. 6.    5 32    Sec. 6.    5 33 corporation status.
  5 34    1.  A benefit corporation may terminate its status as
  5 35 such and cease to be subject to this chapter by amending its
  6  1 articles of incorporation to delete the provision required by
  6  2 section 490B.104 or 490B.105 to be stated in the articles of a
  6  3 benefit corporation.  In order to be effective, the amendment
  6  4 must be adopted by at least the minimum status vote.
  6  5    2.  If a plan of merger, conversion, or share exchange
  6  6 would have the effect of terminating the status of a business
  6  7 corporation as a benefit corporation, the plan must be adopted
  6  8 by at least the minimum status vote in order to be effective.
  6  9 Any sale, lease, exchange, or other disposition of all or
  6 10 substantially all of the assets of a benefit corporation,
  6 11 unless the transaction is in the usual and regular course of
  6 12 business, shall not be effective unless the transaction is
  6 13 approved by at least the minimum status vote.

  6 16    Sec. 7.    6 12 business, shall not be effective unless the transaction is
  6 13 approved by at least the minimum status vote.

  6 15                       CORPORATE PURPOSES
  6 16    Sec. 7.    6 13 approved by at least the minimum status vote.

  6 16    Sec. 7.    6 14                          SUBCHAPTER II
  6 15                       CORPORATE PURPOSES
  6 16    Sec. 7.    6 15                       CORPORATE PURPOSES
  6 16    Sec. 7.    6 16    Sec. 7.    6 17    1.  A benefit corporation shall have a purpose of creating
  6 18 general public benefit.  This purpose is in addition to its
  6 19 purpose under section 490.301.
  6 20    2.  The articles of incorporation of a benefit corporation
  6 21 may identify one or more specific public benefits to be created
  6 22 as a purpose in addition to any purpose provided in section
  6 23 490.301 or subsection 1.  The identification of a specific
  6 24 public benefit under this subsection does not limit the
  6 25 obligation of a benefit corporation under subsection 1.
  6 26    3.  The creation of general public benefit as described
  6 27 in subsection 1 and a specific public benefit as described
  6 28 in subsection 2 is in the best interests of the benefit
  6 29 corporation.
  6 30    4.  A benefit corporation may amend its articles of
  6 31 incorporation to add, amend, or delete the identification of a
  6 32 specific public benefit that it is the purpose of the benefit
  6 33 corporation to create.  In order to be effective, the amendment
  6 34 must be adopted by at least the minimum status vote.
  6 35    5.  A professional corporation that is a benefit corporation
  7  1 does not violate section 496C.4 by having the purpose to
  7  2 create general public benefit as provided in subsection 1 or a
  7  3 specific public benefit as provided in subsection 2.

  7  6    Sec. 8.    7  4                         SUBCHAPTER III
  7  5                         ACCOUNTABILITY
  7  6    Sec. 8.    7  5                         ACCOUNTABILITY
  7  6    Sec. 8.    7  6    Sec. 8.    7  7 directors.
  7  8    1.  In discharging the duties of their respective positions
  7  9 and in considering the best interests of the benefit
  7 10 corporation, a benefit corporation's board of directors,
  7 11 committees, and individual directors shall consider the effects
  7 12 of any action or inaction upon all of the following:
  7 13    a.  The shareholders of the benefit corporation.
  7 14    b.  The employees and workforce of the benefit corporation,
  7 15 its subsidiaries, and its suppliers.
  7 16    c.  The interests of customers as beneficiaries of the
  7 17 general public benefit or specific public benefit purpose of
  7 18 the benefit corporation as provided in section 490B.201.
  7 19    d.  Community or societal factors, including those of
  7 20 each community in which offices or facilities of the benefit
  7 21 corporation, its subsidiaries, or its suppliers are located.
  7 22    e.  The local and global environment.
  7 23    f.  The short=term and long=term interests of the benefit
  7 24 corporation, including but not limited to benefits that may
  7 25 accrue to the benefit corporation from its long=term plans and
  7 26 the possibility that these interests may be best served by the
  7 27 continued independence of the benefit corporation.
  7 28    g.  The ability of the benefit corporation to create general
  7 29 public benefit or any specific public benefit as provided in
  7 30 section 490B.201.
  7 31    2.  In discharging the duties of their respective positions
  7 32 and in considering the best interests of the benefit
  7 33 corporation, a benefit corporation's board of directors,
  7 34 committees, and individual directors may consider any of the
  7 35 following:
  8  1    a.  The interests referred to in section 490.1108A.
  8  2    b.  Any other pertinent factor or the interest of any other
  8  3 person or group of persons deemed appropriate.
  8  4    3.  In discharging the duties of their respective positions
  8  5 and in considering the best interests of the benefit
  8  6 corporation, a benefit corporation's board of directors,
  8  7 committees, and individual directors need not give priority to
  8  8 the interest of a particular person referred to in subsection 1
  8  9 or 2 over the interests of any other person unless the benefit
  8 10 corporation's articles of incorporation state the benefit
  8 11 corporation's intention to give priority to a certain  interest
  8 12 related to its creation of general public benefit or a specific
  8 13 public benefit as provided in section 490B.201.
  8 14    4.  The consideration of an interest or factor in the manner
  8 15 required by  subsections 1 through 3 shall not constitute a
  8 16 violation of section 490.830.
  8 17    5.  Except as provided in the articles of incorporation or
  8 18 bylaws of a benefit corporation, a director is not personally
  8 19 liable for monetary damages for any of the following:
  8 20    a.  An action or inaction in the course of performing the
  8 21 duties of a director under subsections 1 through 3 if the
  8 22 director performed the duties of office in compliance with this
  8 23 section and section 490.830.
  8 24    b.  The failure of the benefit corporation to pursue or
  8 25 create general public benefit or a specific public benefit as
  8 26 provided in section 490B.201.
  8 27    6.  A director of a benefit corporation does not have a duty
  8 28 to a person who is a beneficiary of the general public benefit
  8 29 or a specific public benefit purpose of the benefit corporation
  8 30 as provided in section 490B.201, arising from the status of the
  8 31 person as a beneficiary.
  8 32    7.  A director of a benefit corporation who makes a business
  8 33 judgment in good faith fulfills the duty under this section if
  8 34 all of the following apply:
  8 35    a.  The director is not interested in the subject of the
  9  1 business judgment.
  9  2    b.  The director is informed with respect to the subject of
  9  3 the business judgment to the extent the director reasonably
  9  4 believes to be appropriate under the circumstances.
  9  5    c.  The director rationally believes that the business
  9  6 judgment is in the best interests of the benefit corporation.
  9  7    Sec. 9.    7  8    1.  In discharging the duties of their respective positions

  9  3 the business judgment to the extent the director reasonably
  9  4 believes to be appropriate under the circumstances.
  9  5    c.  The director rationally believes that the business
  9  6 judgment is in the best interests of the benefit corporation.
  9  7    Sec. 9.    7 10 corporation, a benefit corporation's board of directors,
  7 11 committees, and individual directors shall consider the effects
  7 12 of any action or inaction upon all of the following:
  7 13    a.  The shareholders of the benefit corporation.
  7 14    b.  The employees and workforce of the benefit corporation,
  7 15 its subsidiaries, and its suppliers.
  7 16    c.  The interests of customers as beneficiaries of the
  7 17 general public benefit or specific public benefit purpose of
  7 18 the benefit corporation as provided in section 490B.201.
  7 19    d.  Community or societal factors, including those of
  7 20 each community in which offices or facilities of the benefit
  7 21 corporation, its subsidiaries, or its suppliers are located.
  7 22    e.  The local and global environment.
  7 23    f.  The short=term and long=term interests of the benefit
  7 24 corporation, including but not limited to benefits that may
  7 25 accrue to the benefit corporation from its long=term plans and
  7 26 the possibility that these interests may be best served by the
  7 27 continued independence of the benefit corporation.
  7 28    g.  The ability of the benefit corporation to create general
  7 29 public benefit or any specific public benefit as provided in
  7 30 section 490B.201.
  7 31    2.  In discharging the duties of their respective positions
  7 32 and in considering the best interests of the benefit
  7 33 corporation, a benefit corporation's board of directors,
  7 34 committees, and individual directors may consider any of the
  7 35 following:
  8  1    a.  The interests referred to in section 490.1108A.
  8  2    b.  Any other pertinent factor or the interest of any other
  8  3 person or group of persons deemed appropriate.
  8  4    3.  In discharging the duties of their respective positions
  8  5 and in considering the best interests of the benefit
  8  6 corporation, a benefit corporation's board of directors,
  8  7 committees, and individual directors need not give priority to
  8  8 the interest of a particular person referred to in subsection 1
  8  9 or 2 over the interests of any other person unless the benefit
  8 10 corporation's articles of incorporation state the benefit
  8 11 corporation's intention to give priority to a certain  interest
  8 12 related to its creation of general public benefit or a specific
  8 13 public benefit as provided in section 490B.201.
  8 14    4.  The consideration of an interest or factor in the manner
  8 15 required by  subsections 1 through 3 shall not constitute a
  8 16 violation of section 490.830.

  8 18 bylaws of a benefit corporation, a director is not personally

  8 21 duties of a director under subsections 1 through 3 if the
  8 22 director performed the duties of office in compliance with this
  8 23 section and section 490.830.

  9  3 the business judgment to the extent the director reasonably
  9  4 believes to be appropriate under the circumstances.
  9  5    c.  The director rationally believes that the business
  9  6 judgment is in the best interests of the benefit corporation.

  7 20 each community in which offices or facilities of the benefit
  7 21 corporation, its subsidiaries, or its suppliers are located.
  7 22    e.  The local and global environment.

  7 24 corporation, including but not limited to benefits that may
  7 25 accrue to the benefit corporation from its long=term plans and
  7 26 the possibility that these interests may be best served by the
  7 27 continued independence of the benefit corporation.

  7 35 following:
  8  1    a.  The interests referred to in section 490.1108A.

  8  3 person or group of persons deemed appropriate.

  8  5 and in considering the best interests of the benefit

  7 34 committees, and individual directors may consider any of the
  7 35 following:
  8  1    a.  The interests referred to in section 490.1108A.
  8  2    b.  Any other pertinent factor or the interest of any other
  8  3 person or group of persons deemed appropriate.
  8  4    3.  In discharging the duties of their respective positions
  8  5 and in considering the best interests of the benefit
  8  6 corporation, a benefit corporation's board of directors,
  8  7 committees, and individual directors need not give priority to
  8  8 the interest of a particular person referred to in subsection 1
  8  9 or 2 over the interests of any other person unless the benefit
  8 10 corporation's articles of incorporation state the benefit
  8 11 corporation's intention to give priority to a certain  interest
  8 12 related to its creation of general public benefit or a specific
  8 13 public benefit as provided in section 490B.201.
  8 14    4.  The consideration of an interest or factor in the manner
  8 15 required by  subsections 1 through 3 shall not constitute a
  8 16 violation of section 490.830.
  8 17    5.  Except as provided in the articles of incorporation or
  8 18 bylaws of a benefit corporation, a director is not personally
  8 19 liable for monetary damages for any of the following:
  8 20    a.  An action or inaction in the course of performing the
  8 21 duties of a director under subsections 1 through 3 if the
  8 22 director performed the duties of office in compliance with this
  8 23 section and section 490.830.
  8 24    b.  The failure of the benefit corporation to pursue or
  8 25 create general public benefit or a specific public benefit as
  8 26 provided in section 490B.201.
  8 27    6.  A director of a benefit corporation does not have a duty
  8 28 to a person who is a beneficiary of the general public benefit
  8 29 or a specific public benefit purpose of the benefit corporation
  8 30 as provided in section 490B.201, arising from the status of the
  8 31 person as a beneficiary.

  8 33 judgment in good faith fulfills the duty under this section if
  8 34 all of the following apply:
  8 35    a.  The director is not interested in the subject of the
  9  1 business judgment.
  9  2    b.  The director is informed with respect to the subject of
  9  3 the business judgment to the extent the director reasonably
  9  4 believes to be appropriate under the circumstances.
  9  5    c.  The director rationally believes that the business
  9  6 judgment is in the best interests of the benefit corporation.

  8 19 liable for monetary damages for any of the following:
  8 20    a.  An action or inaction in the course of performing the
  8 21 duties of a director under subsections 1 through 3 if the
  8 22 director performed the duties of office in compliance with this
  8 23 section and section 490.830.
  8 24    b.  The failure of the benefit corporation to pursue or
  8 25 create general public benefit or a specific public benefit as
  8 26 provided in section 490B.201.
  8 27    6.  A director of a benefit corporation does not have a duty
  8 28 to a person who is a beneficiary of the general public benefit
  8 29 or a specific public benefit purpose of the benefit corporation
  8 30 as provided in section 490B.201, arising from the status of the
  8 31 person as a beneficiary.
  8 32    7.  A director of a benefit corporation who makes a business
  8 33 judgment in good faith fulfills the duty under this section if
  8 34 all of the following apply:
  8 35    a.  The director is not interested in the subject of the
  9  1 business judgment.
  9  2    b.  The director is informed with respect to the subject of
  9  3 the business judgment to the extent the director reasonably
  9  4 believes to be appropriate under the circumstances.
  9  5    c.  The director rationally believes that the business
  9  6 judgment is in the best interests of the benefit corporation.
  9  7    Sec. 9.    8  4    3.  In discharging the duties of their respective positions
  8  5 and in considering the best interests of the benefit
  8  6 corporation, a benefit corporation's board of directors,
  8  7 committees, and individual directors need not give priority to
  8  8 the interest of a particular person referred to in subsection 1
  8  9 or 2 over the interests of any other person unless the benefit
  8 10 corporation's articles of incorporation state the benefit
  8 11 corporation's intention to give priority to a certain  interest
  8 12 related to its creation of general public benefit or a specific
  8 13 public benefit as provided in section 490B.201.
  8 14    4.  The consideration of an interest or factor in the manner
  8 15 required by  subsections 1 through 3 shall not constitute a
