  9  7    Sec. 9.    9  7    Sec. 9.    9  8    1.  The board of directors of a benefit corporation that is
  9  9 a publicly traded corporation shall, and the board of any other
  9 10 benefit corporation may, include a director who is designated
  9 11 the benefit director. Such director shall have, in addition
  9 12 to the powers, duties, rights, and immunities of the other
  9 13 directors of the benefit corporation, the powers, duties,
  9 14 rights, and immunities provided in this subchapter.
  9 15    2.  a.  A benefit director shall be elected, and may be
  9 16 removed, in the manner provided by chapter 490, division
  9 17 VIII, part A.  The benefit director shall be an individual
  9 18 who is independent.  The benefit director may serve as the
  9 19 benefit officer at the same time as serving as the benefit
  9 20 director.  The articles of incorporation or bylaws of a benefit
  9 21 corporation may prescribe additional qualifications of the
  9 22 benefit director not inconsistent with this paragraph.
  9 23    b.  Notwithstanding paragraph "a", a benefit director of
  9 24 a professional corporation subject to chapter 496C is not
  9 25 required to be independent.
  9 26    3.  The benefit director shall prepare, and the benefit
  9 27 corporation shall include in the annual benefit report to
  9 28 shareholders required by section 490B.401, the opinion of the
  9 29 benefit director regarding all of the following:
  9 30    a.  Whether the benefit corporation acted in accordance
  9 31 with its general public benefit and any specific public
  9 32 benefit purpose as provided in section 490B.201 in all material
  9 33 respects during the period covered by the report.
  9 34    b.  Whether the directors and officers complied with section
  9 35 490B.301, subsection 1, and section 490B.303, subsection 1,
 10  1 respectively.
 10  2    c.  If, in the opinion of the benefit director, the benefit
 10  3 corporation's directors or officers failed to comply with
 10  4 paragraph "b", a description of the ways in which the benefit
 10  5 corporation's directors or officers failed to comply.
 10  6    4.  An act or inaction of an individual in the capacity of a
 10  7 benefit director shall constitute for all purposes an act or
 10  8 inaction of that individual in the capacity of a director of
 10  9 the benefit corporation.
 10 10    5.  Regardless of whether the articles of incorporation or
 10 11 bylaws of a benefit corporation include a provision eliminating
 10 12 or limiting the personal liability of a director authorized by
 10 13 section 490.202, a benefit director is not personally liable
 10 14 for an act or omission in the director's capacity as a benefit
 10 15 director unless the act or omission constitutes self=dealing,
 10 16 willful misconduct, or a knowing violation of law.

 10  2    c.  If, in the opinion of the benefit director, the benefit
 10  3 corporation's directors or officers failed to comply with
 10  4 paragraph "b", a description of the ways in which the benefit
 10  5 corporation's directors or officers failed to comply.
 10  6    4.  An act or inaction of an individual in the capacity of a
 10  7 benefit director shall constitute for all purposes an act or
 10  8 inaction of that individual in the capacity of a director of
 10  9 the benefit corporation.
 10 10    5.  Regardless of whether the articles of incorporation or
 10 11 bylaws of a benefit corporation include a provision eliminating
 10 12 or limiting the personal liability of a director authorized by
 10 13 section 490.202, a benefit director is not personally liable
 10 14 for an act or omission in the director's capacity as a benefit
 10 15 director unless the act or omission constitutes self=dealing,
 10 16 willful misconduct, or a knowing violation of law.
 10 17    Sec. 10.    9 14 rights, and immunities provided in this subchapter.
  9 15    2.  a.  A benefit director shall be elected, and may be
  9 16 removed, in the manner provided by chapter 490, division
  9 17 VIII, part A.  The benefit director shall be an individual
  9 18 who is independent.  The benefit director may serve as the
  9 19 benefit officer at the same time as serving as the benefit
  9 20 director.  The articles of incorporation or bylaws of a benefit
  9 21 corporation may prescribe additional qualifications of the
  9 22 benefit director not inconsistent with this paragraph.
  9 23    b.  Notwithstanding paragraph "a", a benefit director of
  9 24 a professional corporation subject to chapter 496C is not
  9 25 required to be independent.

 10 17    Sec. 10.   10 17    Sec. 10.   10 18 officers.
 10 19    1.  Each officer of a benefit corporation shall consider the
 10 20 interests and factors described in section 490B.301, subsection
 10 21 1, in the manner provided in that subsection if all of the
 10 22 following apply:
 10 23    a.  The officer has discretion to act with respect to a
 10 24 matter.
 10 25    b.  It reasonably appears to the officer that the matter
 10 26 may have a material effect on the creation by the benefit
 10 27 corporation of general public benefit or a specific public
 10 28 benefit as provided in section 490B.201.
 10 29    2.  The consideration of  the best interests of the benefit
 10 30 corporation in the manner described in subsection 1 shall not
 10 31 constitute a violation of section 490.842.
 10 32    3.  Except as provided in the articles of incorporation or
 10 33 bylaws of a benefit corporation, an officer is not personally
 10 34 liable for monetary damages for any of the following:
 10 35    a.  An action or inaction as an officer in the course of
 11  1 performing the duties of an officer under subsection 1 if the
 11  2 officer performed the duties of the position in compliance with
 11  3 section 490.842 and this section.
 11  4    b.  The failure of the benefit corporation to pursue or
 11  5 create general public benefit or a specific public benefit as
 11  6 provided in section 490B.201.
 11  7    4.  An officer does not have a duty to a person who is a
 11  8 beneficiary of the general public benefit or a specific public
 11  9 benefit purpose of the benefit corporation, as provided in
 11 10 section 490B.201, arising from the status of the person as a
 11 11 beneficiary.
 11 12    5.  An officer who makes a business judgment in good faith
 11 13 fulfills the duty under this section if all of the following
 11 14 apply:
 11 15    a.  The officer is not interested in the subject of the
 11 16 business judgment.
 11 17    b.  The officer is informed with respect to the subject of
 11 18 the business judgment to the extent the officer reasonably
 11 19 believes to be appropriate under the circumstances.
 11 20    c.  The officer rationally believes that the business
 11 21 judgment is in the best interests of the benefit corporation.

 11 26 relating to the purpose of the corporation to create general
 11 27 public benefit or a specific public benefit as provided in
 11 28 section 490B.201, if authorized by any of the following:
 11 29    (1)  The articles of incorporation or bylaws of the benefit
 11 30 corporation.
 11 31    (2)  Absent any controlling provisions in the articles
 11 32 of incorporation or bylaws of the benefit corporation, by
 11 33 resolution or  order of the benefit corporation's board of
 11 34 directors.

 12  2    Sec. 12.   12  2    Sec. 12.   12  3 directors ==== criteria for independence.
 12  4    1.  Serving as a benefit director or benefit officer
 12  5 shall not alone affect whether an individual is or is not
 12  6 independent.
 12  7    2.  A material relationship between an individual and a
 12  8 benefit corporation or any of its subsidiaries is conclusively
 12  9 presumed to exist if any of the following apply:
 12 10    a.  The individual is, or has been within the last three
 12 11 years, an employee other than a benefit officer of the benefit
 12 12 corporation or a subsidiary.
 12 13    b.  An immediate family member of the individual is, or
 12 14 has been within the last three years, an executive officer
 12 15 other than a benefit officer of the benefit corporation or a
 12 16 subsidiary.
 12 17    c.  There is beneficial or record ownership of five percent
 12 18 or more of the outstanding shares of the benefit corporation,
 12 19 calculated as if all outstanding rights to acquire equity
 12 20 interests in the benefit corporation had been exercised, by any
 12 21 of the following:
 12 22    (1)  The individual.
 12 23    (2)  An entity if any of the following apply:
 12 24    (a)  The individual is a director, an officer, or a manager
 12 25 of the entity.
 12 26    (b)  The individual owns beneficially or of record five
 12 27 percent or more of the entity's outstanding equity interests,
 12 28 calculated as if all outstanding rights to acquire equity
 12 29 interests in the entity had been exercised.

 12 30    Sec. 13.   12 30    Sec. 13.   12 31 enforcement proceedings.
 12 32    1.  a.  Except in a benefit enforcement proceeding, a person
 12 33 shall not bring an action or assert a claim against a benefit
 12 34 corporation or its directors or officers with respect to any
 12 35 of the following:
 13  1    (1)  The failure of the benefit corporation to pursue or
 13  2 create general public benefit or a specific public benefit
 13  3 as set forth in its articles of incorporation as provided in
 13  4 section 490B.201.
 13  5    (2)  A violation of an obligation, duty, or standard of
 13  6 conduct under this chapter.
 13  7    b.  A benefit corporation shall not be liable for monetary
 13  8 damages under this chapter for any failure of the benefit
 13  9 corporation to pursue or create general public benefit or a
 13 10 specific public benefit as provided in section 490B.201.
 13 11    2.  A benefit enforcement proceeding may be commenced or
 13 12 maintained only as follows:
 13 13    a.  Directly by the benefit corporation.
 13 14    b.  Derivatively, in accordance with chapter 490, division
 13 15 VII, part D by any of the following:
 13 16    (1)  A person or group of persons that owns beneficially or
 13 17 of record at least two percent of the total number of shares
 13 18 of all classes and series outstanding on the date of the
 13 19 complained of action or inaction.
 13 20    (2)  A director of the benefit corporation.
 13 21    (3)  A person or group of persons that owns beneficially
 13 22 or of record  five percent or more of the outstanding equity
 13 23 interests in an entity of which the benefit corporation is a
 13 24 subsidiary on the date of the complained of action or inaction.
 13 25    (4)  Any other person or group of persons as specified in the
 13 26 articles of incorporation or bylaws of the benefit corporation.
 13 27    3.  For purposes of this section, a person is the beneficial
 13 28 owner of shares or equity interests if the shares or equity
 13 29 interests are held in a voting trust or by a nominee on behalf
 13 30 of the beneficial owner.

 13 32                          TRANSPARENCY
 13 33    Sec. 14.   12 34 corporation or its directors or officers with respect to any
 12 35 of the following:
 13  1    (1)  The failure of the benefit corporation to pursue or
 13  2 create general public benefit or a specific public benefit
 13  3 as set forth in its articles of incorporation as provided in
 13  4 section 490B.201.
 13  5    (2)  A violation of an obligation, duty, or standard of
 13  6 conduct under this chapter.
 13  7    b.  A benefit corporation shall not be liable for monetary
 13  8 damages under this chapter for any failure of the benefit
 13  9 corporation to pursue or create general public benefit or a
 13 10 specific public benefit as provided in section 490B.201.
 13 11    2.  A benefit enforcement proceeding may be commenced or
 13 12 maintained only as follows:
 13 13    a.  Directly by the benefit corporation.
 13 14    b.  Derivatively, in accordance with chapter 490, division
 13 15 VII, part D by any of the following:
 13 16    (1)  A person or group of persons that owns beneficially or
 13 17 of record at least two percent of the total number of shares
 13 18 of all classes and series outstanding on the date of the
 13 19 complained of action or inaction.
 13 20    (2)  A director of the benefit corporation.
 13 21    (3)  A person or group of persons that owns beneficially
 13 22 or of record  five percent or more of the outstanding equity
 13 23 interests in an entity of which the benefit corporation is a
 13 24 subsidiary on the date of the complained of action or inaction.
 13 25    (4)  Any other person or group of persons as specified in the
 13 26 articles of incorporation or bylaws of the benefit corporation.
 13 27    3.  For purposes of this section, a person is the beneficial
 13 28 owner of shares or equity interests if the shares or equity
 13 29 interests are held in a voting trust or by a nominee on behalf
 13 30 of the beneficial owner.

 13 26 articles of incorporation or bylaws of the benefit corporation.
 13 27    3.  For purposes of this section, a person is the beneficial
 13 28 owner of shares or equity interests if the shares or equity
 13 29 interests are held in a voting trust or by a nominee on behalf
 13 30 of the beneficial owner.

 13 33    Sec. 14.   13 33    Sec. 14.   13 34 benefit report.
 13 35    1.  A benefit corporation shall prepare an annual benefit
 14  1 report which shall include at least all of the following:
 14  2    a.  A narrative description of all of the following:
 14  3    (1)  The ways in which the benefit corporation pursued or
 14  4 created general public benefit.
 14  5    (2)  The ways in which the benefit corporation pursued
 14  6 or created a specific public benefit, as provided in section
 14  7 490B.201, to the extent that the specific public benefit is
 14  8 stated in the benefit corporation's articles of incorporation.
 14  9    (3)  Any circumstances that have hindered the pursuit or
 14 10 creation of general public benefit or a specific public benefit
 14 11 as provided in section 490B.201.
 14 12    (4)  The process and rationale for selecting or changing the
 14 13 third=party standard used to prepare the benefit report.
 14 14    b.  An assessment of the overall social and environmental
 14 15 performance of the benefit corporation against a third=party
 14 16 standard that is all of the following:
 14 17    (1)  Applied consistently with any application of the
 14 18 third=party standard in prior benefit reports.
 14 19    (2)  Accompanied by an explanation of the reasons for any of
 14 20 the following:
 14 21    (a)  Inconsistent application.
 14 22    (b)  A change to the third=party standard from the standard
 14 23 used in the immediately prior report.
 14 24    c.  The name of the benefit director and the benefit officer,
 14 25 if any, and the address to which correspondence to each of them
 14 26 may be directed.
 14 27    d.  The compensation paid by the benefit corporation, during
 14 28 the year, to each director in the capacity of a director.
 14 29    e.  The opinion of the benefit director described in section
 14 30 490B.302, subsection 3.
 14 31    f.  A statement of any connection between the organization
 14 32 that established the third=party standard, or its directors,
 14 33 officers, or any holder of five percent or more of the
 14 34 governance interests in the organization, and the benefit
 14 35 corporation or its directors, officers, or any holder of five
 15  1 percent or more of the outstanding shares of the benefit
 15  2 corporation, including any financial or governance relationship
 15  3 which might materially affect the credibility of the use of the
 15  4 third=party standard.
 15  5    2.  If, during the year covered by a benefit report,
 15  6 a benefit director resigned from or refused to stand for
 15  7 reelection to the position of benefit director, or was removed
 15  8 from the position of benefit director, and the benefit director
 15  9 furnished the benefit corporation with written correspondence
 15 10 concerning the circumstances surrounding the resignation,
 15 11 refusal, or removal, the benefit report shall include that
 15 12 correspondence as an exhibit.
 15 13    3.  Neither the benefit report nor the assessment of the
 15 14 performance of the benefit corporation in the benefit report
 15 15 required by subsection 1, paragraph "b", is required to be
 15 16 audited or certified by a third party.

 15  5    2.  If, during the year covered by a benefit report,
 15  6 a benefit director resigned from or refused to stand for
 15  7 reelection to the position of benefit director, or was removed
 15  8 from the position of benefit director, and the benefit director
 15  9 furnished the benefit corporation with written correspondence
 15 10 concerning the circumstances surrounding the resignation,
 15 11 refusal, or removal, the benefit report shall include that
 15 12 correspondence as an exhibit.
 15 13    3.  Neither the benefit report nor the assessment of the
 15 14 performance of the benefit corporation in the benefit report
 15 15 required by subsection 1, paragraph "b", is required to be
 15 16 audited or certified by a third party.

 15 19    1.  A benefit corporation shall send its annual benefit
 15 20 report to each shareholder on the earlier of any of the
 15 21 following:
 15 22    a.  One hundred twenty days following the end of the fiscal
 15 23 year of the benefit corporation.
 15 24    b.  The date that the benefit corporation delivers any other
 15 25 annual report to its shareholders.
 15 26    2.  A benefit corporation shall post all of its benefit
 15 27 reports on the public portion of its internet site, if any.
 15 28 However, the compensation paid to directors and financial or
 15 29 proprietary information included in a benefit report required
 15 30 pursuant to section 490B.401 may be omitted from the benefit
 15 31 reports as posted.
 15 32    3.  a.  Concurrently with the delivery of the benefit report
 15 33 to shareholders under subsection 1, the benefit corporation
 15 34 shall deliver a copy of the benefit report to the  secretary
 15 35 of  state for filing.  However, the compensation paid to
 16  1 directors and financial or proprietary information included in
 16  2 the benefit report may be omitted from the benefit report as
 16  3 delivered to the secretary of state.
 16  4    b.  The secretary of state may impose and collect a fee of
 16  5 not more than ten dollars for filing a benefit report.
 16  6                           EXPLANATION
 16  7 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 16  8 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 16  9    GENERAL.  This bill allows a business corporation to
 16 10 incorporate and operate as a benefit corporation, generally
 16 11 subject to the Iowa business corporation Act (Code chapter 490)
 16 12 except as  provided in the bill's new Code chapter (Code chapter
 16 13 490B).
 16 14    ELECTION TO ATTAIN OR TERMINATE BENEFIT CORPORATION STATUS.
 16 15  The bill provides that a business corporation attains or
 16 16 terminates its status as a benefit corporation by shareholder
 16 17 election.
 16 18    ARTICLES OF INCORPORATION.  The bill provides that a
 16 19 benefit corporation's articles of incorporation must have as a
 16 20 purpose the creation of general public benefit which provides
 16 21 a material positive impact on society and the environment as
 16 22 assessed against a third=party standard. The bill provides
 16 23 that a benefit  corporation's articles of incorporation may list
 16 24 one or more  specific public purposes.
 16 25    BOARD ACTION.  The bill requires a benefit corporation's
 16 26 board of directors, in addition to its fiduciary duty to make
 16 27 decisions based on financial interests, to also consider
 16 28 factors associated with creating general public benefit or
 16 29 furthering a specific public benefit, or other beneficial goal.
 16 30 The bill limits a director's personal liability due to any
 16 31 failure of the benefit corporation to accomplish a general or
 16 32 specific public benefit purpose.
 16 33    LEGAL ACTIONS.  The bill prohibits a person from bringing an
 16 34 action against a benefit corporation or its directors, except
 16 35 in a benefit enforcement proceeding. A benefit enforcement
 17  1 proceeding can only be commenced by the benefit corporation
 17  2 or derivatively by a person or group that holds shares in
 17  3 the corporation or an equity interest in the corporation, by
 17  4 a director, or by any other person or group provided in the
 17  5 articles of incorporation.
 17  6    BENEFIT DIRECTOR AND OFFICER.  The bill requires a public
 17  7 corporation's board of directors to include a benefit director.
 17  8 A privately held benefit corporation's board may include
 17  9 such director. Such director must be independent, having
 17 10 no material relationship with the benefit corporation.  The
 17 11 bill provides that a benefit corporation may have a benefit
 17 12 officer who is charged with overseeing the creation of the
 17 13 corporation's general public benefit or a specific public
 17 14 benefit.
 17 15    REPORT.  The bill requires a benefit corporation to prepare
 17 16 an annual benefit report to its shareholders. The report must
 17 17 include information regarding the third=party standard used
 17 18 to  prepare the benefit report, the ways in which the benefit
 17 19 corporation pursued its general and specific public benefits,
 17 20 and an assessment of the overall social and environmental
 17 21 performance of the benefit corporation indicating whether
 17 22 the benefit corporation pursued its general or any specific
 17 23 public benefit purpose. The bill also requires the benefit
 17 24 corporation to file the benefit report with the secretary of
 17 25 state and pay the secretary of state a filing fee.
       LSB 5453YH (2) 86
       da/nh
 15 19    1.  A benefit corporation shall send its annual benefit
 15 20 report to each shareholder on the earlier of any of the
 15 21 following:
 15 22    a.  One hundred twenty days following the end of the fiscal
 15 23 year of the benefit corporation.
 15 24    b.  The date that the benefit corporation delivers any other
 15 25 annual report to its shareholders.
 15 26    2.  A benefit corporation shall post all of its benefit
 15 27 reports on the public portion of its internet site, if any.
 15 28 However, the compensation paid to directors and financial or
 15 29 proprietary information included in a benefit report required
 15 30 pursuant to section 490B.401 may be omitted from the benefit
 15 31 reports as posted.
 15 32    3.  a.  Concurrently with the delivery of the benefit report
 15 33 to shareholders under subsection 1, the benefit corporation
 15 34 shall deliver a copy of the benefit report to the  secretary
 15 35 of  state for filing.  However, the compensation paid to
 16  1 directors and financial or proprietary information included in
 16  2 the benefit report may be omitted from the benefit report as
 16  3 delivered to the secretary of state.
 16  4    b.  The secretary of state may impose and collect a fee of
 16  5 not more than ten dollars for filing a benefit report.

 16 33    LEGAL ACTIONS.  The bill prohibits a person from bringing an
 16 34 action against a benefit corporation or its directors, except
 16 35 in a benefit enforcement proceeding. A benefit enforcement
 17  1 proceeding can only be commenced by the benefit corporation
 17  2 or derivatively by a person or group that holds shares in
 17  3 the corporation or an equity interest in the corporation, by
 17  4 a director, or by any other person or group provided in the
 17  5 articles of incorporation.
 17  6    BENEFIT DIRECTOR AND OFFICER.  The bill requires a public
 17  7 corporation's board of directors to include a benefit director.
 17  8 A privately held benefit corporation's board may include
 17  9 such director. Such director must be independent, having
 17 10 no material relationship with the benefit corporation.  The
 17 11 bill provides that a benefit corporation may have a benefit
 17 12 officer who is charged with overseeing the creation of the
 17 13 corporation's general public benefit or a specific public
 17 14 benefit.
 17 15    REPORT.  The bill requires a benefit corporation to prepare
 17 16 an annual benefit report to its shareholders. The report must
 17 17 include information regarding the third=party standard used
 17 18 to  prepare the benefit report, the ways in which the benefit
 17 19 corporation pursued its general and specific public benefits,
 17 20 and an assessment of the overall social and environmental
 17 21 performance of the benefit corporation indicating whether
 17 22 the benefit corporation pursued its general or any specific
 17 23 public benefit purpose. The bill also requires the benefit
 17 24 corporation to file the benefit report with the secretary of
 17 25 state and pay the secretary of state a filing fee.
       LSB 5453YH (2) 86
       da/nh
 15 20 report to each shareholder on the earlier of any of the
 15 21 following:
 15 22    a.  One hundred twenty days following the end of the fiscal
 15 23 year of the benefit corporation.
 15 24    b.  The date that the benefit corporation delivers any other
 15 25 annual report to its shareholders.
 15 26    2.  A benefit corporation shall post all of its benefit
 15 27 reports on the public portion of its internet site, if any.
 15 28 However, the compensation paid to directors and financial or
 15 29 proprietary information included in a benefit report required
 15 30 pursuant to section 490B.401 may be omitted from the benefit
 15 31 reports as posted.
 15 32    3.  a.  Concurrently with the delivery of the benefit report
 15 33 to shareholders under subsection 1, the benefit corporation
 15 34 shall deliver a copy of the benefit report to the  secretary
 15 35 of  state for filing.  However, the compensation paid to
 16  1 directors and financial or proprietary information included in
 16  2 the benefit report may be omitted from the benefit report as
 16  3 delivered to the secretary of state.
 16  4    b.  The secretary of state may impose and collect a fee of
 16  5 not more than ten dollars for filing a benefit report.
 16  6                           EXPLANATION
 16  7 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 16  8 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 16  9    GENERAL.  This bill allows a business corporation to
 16 10 incorporate and operate as a benefit corporation, generally
 16 11 subject to the Iowa business corporation Act (Code chapter 490)
 16 12 except as  provided in the bill's new Code chapter (Code chapter
 16 13 490B).
 16 14    ELECTION TO ATTAIN OR TERMINATE BENEFIT CORPORATION STATUS.
 16 15  The bill provides that a business corporation attains or
 16 16 terminates its status as a benefit corporation by shareholder
 16 17 election.
 16 18    ARTICLES OF INCORPORATION.  The bill provides that a
 16 19 benefit corporation's articles of incorporation must have as a
 16 20 purpose the creation of general public benefit which provides
 16 21 a material positive impact on society and the environment as
 16 22 assessed against a third=party standard. The bill provides
 16 23 that a benefit  corporation's articles of incorporation may list
 16 24 one or more  specific public purposes.
 16 25    BOARD ACTION.  The bill requires a benefit corporation's
 16 26 board of directors, in addition to its fiduciary duty to make
 16 27 decisions based on financial interests, to also consider
 16 28 factors associated with creating general public benefit or
 16 29 furthering a specific public benefit, or other beneficial goal.
 16 30 The bill limits a director's personal liability due to any
 16 31 failure of the benefit corporation to accomplish a general or
 16 32 specific public benefit purpose.
 16 33    LEGAL ACTIONS.  The bill prohibits a person from bringing an
 16 34 action against a benefit corporation or its directors, except
 16 35 in a benefit enforcement proceeding. A benefit enforcement
 17  1 proceeding can only be commenced by the benefit corporation
 17  2 or derivatively by a person or group that holds shares in
 17  3 the corporation or an equity interest in the corporation, by
 17  4 a director, or by any other person or group provided in the
 17  5 articles of incorporation.
 17  6    BENEFIT DIRECTOR AND OFFICER.  The bill requires a public
 17  7 corporation's board of directors to include a benefit director.
 17  8 A privately held benefit corporation's board may include
 17  9 such director. Such director must be independent, having
 17 10 no material relationship with the benefit corporation.  The
 17 11 bill provides that a benefit corporation may have a benefit
 17 12 officer who is charged with overseeing the creation of the
 17 13 corporation's general public benefit or a specific public
 17 14 benefit.
 17 15    REPORT.  The bill requires a benefit corporation to prepare
 17 16 an annual benefit report to its shareholders. The report must
 17 17 include information regarding the third=party standard used
 17 18 to  prepare the benefit report, the ways in which the benefit
 17 19 corporation pursued its general and specific public benefits,
 17 20 and an assessment of the overall social and environmental
 17 21 performance of the benefit corporation indicating whether
 17 22 the benefit corporation pursued its general or any specific
 17 23 public benefit purpose. The bill also requires the benefit
 17 24 corporation to file the benefit report with the secretary of
 17 25 state and pay the secretary of state a filing fee.
       LSB 5453YH (2) 86

 16  5 not more than ten dollars for filing a benefit report.
 16  6                           EXPLANATION
 16  7 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 16  8 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 16  9    GENERAL.  This bill allows a business corporation to
 16 10 incorporate and operate as a benefit corporation, generally
 16 11 subject to the Iowa business corporation Act (Code chapter 490)
 16 12 except as  provided in the bill's new Code chapter (Code chapter
 16 13 490B).
 16 14    ELECTION TO ATTAIN OR TERMINATE BENEFIT CORPORATION STATUS.
 16 15  The bill provides that a business corporation attains or
 16 16 terminates its status as a benefit corporation by shareholder
 16 17 election.
 16 18    ARTICLES OF INCORPORATION.  The bill provides that a
 16 19 benefit corporation's articles of incorporation must have as a
 16 20 purpose the creation of general public benefit which provides
 16 21 a material positive impact on society and the environment as
 16 22 assessed against a third=party standard. The bill provides
 16 23 that a benefit  corporation's articles of incorporation may list
 16 24 one or more  specific public purposes.
 16 25    BOARD ACTION.  The bill requires a benefit corporation's
 16 26 board of directors, in addition to its fiduciary duty to make
 16 27 decisions based on financial interests, to also consider
 16 28 factors associated with creating general public benefit or
 16 29 furthering a specific public benefit, or other beneficial goal.
 16 30 The bill limits a director's personal liability due to any
 16 31 failure of the benefit corporation to accomplish a general or
 16 32 specific public benefit purpose.
 16 33    LEGAL ACTIONS.  The bill prohibits a person from bringing an
 16 34 action against a benefit corporation or its directors, except
 16 35 in a benefit enforcement proceeding. A benefit enforcement
 17  1 proceeding can only be commenced by the benefit corporation
 17  2 or derivatively by a person or group that holds shares in
 17  3 the corporation or an equity interest in the corporation, by
 17  4 a director, or by any other person or group provided in the
 17  5 articles of incorporation.
 17  6    BENEFIT DIRECTOR AND OFFICER.  The bill requires a public
 17  7 corporation's board of directors to include a benefit director.
 17  8 A privately held benefit corporation's board may include
 17  9 such director. Such director must be independent, having
 17 10 no material relationship with the benefit corporation.  The
 17 11 bill provides that a benefit corporation may have a benefit
 17 12 officer who is charged with overseeing the creation of the
 17 13 corporation's general public benefit or a specific public
 17 14 benefit.
 17 15    REPORT.  The bill requires a benefit corporation to prepare
 17 16 an annual benefit report to its shareholders. The report must
 17 17 include information regarding the third=party standard used
 17 18 to  prepare the benefit report, the ways in which the benefit
 17 19 corporation pursued its general and specific public benefits,
 17 20 and an assessment of the overall social and environmental
 17 21 performance of the benefit corporation indicating whether
 17 22 the benefit corporation pursued its general or any specific
 17 23 public benefit purpose. The bill also requires the benefit
 17 24 corporation to file the benefit report with the secretary of
 17 25 state and pay the secretary of state a filing fee.
       LSB 5453YH (2) 86
       da/nh
 15 28 However, the compensation paid to directors and financial or
 15 29 proprietary information included in a benefit report required
 15 30 pursuant to section 490B.401 may be omitted from the benefit
 15 31 reports as posted.
 15 32    3.  a.  Concurrently with the delivery of the benefit report
 15 33 to shareholders under subsection 1, the benefit corporation
 15 34 shall deliver a copy of the benefit report to the  secretary
 15 35 of  state for filing.  However, the compensation paid to
 16  1 directors and financial or proprietary information included in
 16  2 the benefit report may be omitted from the benefit report as
 16  3 delivered to the secretary of state.
 16  4    b.  The secretary of state may impose and collect a fee of
 16  5 not more than ten dollars for filing a benefit report.

 17  3 the corporation or an equity interest in the corporation, by
 17  4 a director, or by any other person or group provided in the
 17  5 articles of incorporation.
 17  6    BENEFIT DIRECTOR AND OFFICER.  The bill requires a public
 17  7 corporation's board of directors to include a benefit director.
 17  8 A privately held benefit corporation's board may include
 17  9 such director. Such director must be independent, having
 17 10 no material relationship with the benefit corporation.  The
 17 11 bill provides that a benefit corporation may have a benefit
 17 12 officer who is charged with overseeing the creation of the
 17 13 corporation's general public benefit or a specific public
 17 14 benefit.
 17 15    REPORT.  The bill requires a benefit corporation to prepare
 17 16 an annual benefit report to its shareholders. The report must
 17 17 include information regarding the third=party standard used
 17 18 to  prepare the benefit report, the ways in which the benefit
 17 19 corporation pursued its general and specific public benefits,
 17 20 and an assessment of the overall social and environmental
 17 21 performance of the benefit corporation indicating whether
 17 22 the benefit corporation pursued its general or any specific
 17 23 public benefit purpose. The bill also requires the benefit
 17 24 corporation to file the benefit report with the secretary of
 17 25 state and pay the secretary of state a filing fee.
       LSB 5453YH (2) 86
       da/nh
 16  1 directors and financial or proprietary information included in
 16  2 the benefit report may be omitted from the benefit report as
 16  3 delivered to the secretary of state.
 16  4    b.  The secretary of state may impose and collect a fee of
 16  5 not more than ten dollars for filing a benefit report.
 16  6                           EXPLANATION
 16  7 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 16  8 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 16  9    GENERAL.  This bill allows a business corporation to
 16 10 incorporate and operate as a benefit corporation, generally
 16 11 subject to the Iowa business corporation Act (Code chapter 490)
 16 12 except as  provided in the bill's new Code chapter (Code chapter
 16 13 490B).
 16 14    ELECTION TO ATTAIN OR TERMINATE BENEFIT CORPORATION STATUS.
 16 15  The bill provides that a business corporation attains or
 16 16 terminates its status as a benefit corporation by shareholder
 16 17 election.
 16 18    ARTICLES OF INCORPORATION.  The bill provides that a
 16 19 benefit corporation's articles of incorporation must have as a
 16 20 purpose the creation of general public benefit which provides
 16 21 a material positive impact on society and the environment as
 16 22 assessed against a third=party standard. The bill provides
 16 23 that a benefit  corporation's articles of incorporation may list
 16 24 one or more  specific public purposes.
 16 25    BOARD ACTION.  The bill requires a benefit corporation's
 16 26 board of directors, in addition to its fiduciary duty to make
 16 27 decisions based on financial interests, to also consider
 16 28 factors associated with creating general public benefit or
 16 29 furthering a specific public benefit, or other beneficial goal.
 16 30 The bill limits a director's personal liability due to any
 16 31 failure of the benefit corporation to accomplish a general or
 16 32 specific public benefit purpose.
 16 33    LEGAL ACTIONS.  The bill prohibits a person from bringing an
 16 34 action against a benefit corporation or its directors, except
 16 35 in a benefit enforcement proceeding. A benefit enforcement
 17  1 proceeding can only be commenced by the benefit corporation
 17  2 or derivatively by a person or group that holds shares in
 17  3 the corporation or an equity interest in the corporation, by
 17  4 a director, or by any other person or group provided in the
 17  5 articles of incorporation.
 17  6    BENEFIT DIRECTOR AND OFFICER.  The bill requires a public
 17  7 corporation's board of directors to include a benefit director.
 17  8 A privately held benefit corporation's board may include
 17  9 such director. Such director must be independent, having
 17 10 no material relationship with the benefit corporation.  The
 17 11 bill provides that a benefit corporation may have a benefit
 17 12 officer who is charged with overseeing the creation of the
 17 13 corporation's general public benefit or a specific public
 17 14 benefit.
 17 15    REPORT.  The bill requires a benefit corporation to prepare
 17 16 an annual benefit report to its shareholders. The report must
 17 17 include information regarding the third=party standard used
 17 18 to  prepare the benefit report, the ways in which the benefit
 17 19 corporation pursued its general and specific public benefits,
 17 20 and an assessment of the overall social and environmental
 17 21 performance of the benefit corporation indicating whether
 17 22 the benefit corporation pursued its general or any specific
 17 23 public benefit purpose. The bill also requires the benefit
 17 24 corporation to file the benefit report with the secretary of
 17 25 state and pay the secretary of state a filing fee.
       LSB 5453YH (2) 86
       da/nh
 16  2 the benefit report may be omitted from the benefit report as
 16  3 delivered to the secretary of state.
 16  4    b.  The secretary of state may impose and collect a fee of
 16  5 not more than ten dollars for filing a benefit report.

 16 33    LEGAL ACTIONS.  The bill prohibits a person from bringing an
 16 34 action against a benefit corporation or its directors, except
 16 35 in a benefit enforcement proceeding. A benefit enforcement
 17  1 proceeding can only be commenced by the benefit corporation
 17  2 or derivatively by a person or group that holds shares in
 17  3 the corporation or an equity interest in the corporation, by
 17  4 a director, or by any other person or group provided in the
 17  5 articles of incorporation.
 17  6    BENEFIT DIRECTOR AND OFFICER.  The bill requires a public
 17  7 corporation's board of directors to include a benefit director.
 17  8 A privately held benefit corporation's board may include
 17  9 such director. Such director must be independent, having
 17 10 no material relationship with the benefit corporation.  The
 17 11 bill provides that a benefit corporation may have a benefit
 17 12 officer who is charged with overseeing the creation of the
 17 13 corporation's general public benefit or a specific public
 17 14 benefit.
 17 15    REPORT.  The bill requires a benefit corporation to prepare
 17 16 an annual benefit report to its shareholders. The report must
 17 17 include information regarding the third=party standard used
 17 18 to  prepare the benefit report, the ways in which the benefit
 17 19 corporation pursued its general and specific public benefits,
 17 20 and an assessment of the overall social and environmental
 17 21 performance of the benefit corporation indicating whether
 17 22 the benefit corporation pursued its general or any specific
 17 23 public benefit purpose. The bill also requires the benefit
 17 24 corporation to file the benefit report with the secretary of
 17 25 state and pay the secretary of state a filing fee.
       LSB 5453YH (2) 86
       da/nh
 16 11 subject to the Iowa business corporation Act (Code chapter 490)
 16 12 except as  provided in the bill's new Code chapter (Code chapter
 16 13 490B).
 16 14    ELECTION TO ATTAIN OR TERMINATE BENEFIT CORPORATION STATUS.
 16 15  The bill provides that a business corporation attains or
 16 16 terminates its status as a benefit corporation by shareholder
 16 17 election.
 16 18    ARTICLES OF INCORPORATION.  The bill provides that a
 16 19 benefit corporation's articles of incorporation must have as a
 16 20 purpose the creation of general public benefit which provides
 16 21 a material positive impact on society and the environment as
 16 22 assessed against a third=party standard. The bill provides
 16 23 that a benefit  corporation's articles of incorporation may list
 16 24 one or more  specific public purposes.
 16 25    BOARD ACTION.  The bill requires a benefit corporation's
 16 26 board of directors, in addition to its fiduciary duty to make
 16 27 decisions based on financial interests, to also consider
 16 28 factors associated with creating general public benefit or
 16 29 furthering a specific public benefit, or other beneficial goal.
 16 30 The bill limits a director's personal liability due to any
 16 31 failure of the benefit corporation to accomplish a general or
 16 32 specific public benefit purpose.
 16 33    LEGAL ACTIONS.  The bill prohibits a person from bringing an
 16 34 action against a benefit corporation or its directors, except
 16 35 in a benefit enforcement proceeding. A benefit enforcement
 17  1 proceeding can only be commenced by the benefit corporation
 17  2 or derivatively by a person or group that holds shares in
 17  3 the corporation or an equity interest in the corporation, by
 17  4 a director, or by any other person or group provided in the
 17  5 articles of incorporation.

 17 16 an annual benefit report to its shareholders. The report must
 17 17 include information regarding the third=party standard used
 17 18 to  prepare the benefit report, the ways in which the benefit
 17 19 corporation pursued its general and specific public benefits,
 17 20 and an assessment of the overall social and environmental
 17 21 performance of the benefit corporation indicating whether
 17 22 the benefit corporation pursued its general or any specific
 17 23 public benefit purpose. The bill also requires the benefit
 17 24 corporation to file the benefit report with the secretary of
 17 25 state and pay the secretary of state a filing fee.
       LSB 5453YH (2) 86
       da/nh
 16 23 that a benefit  corporation's articles of incorporation may list
 16 24 one or more  specific public purposes.
 16 25    BOARD ACTION.  The bill requires a benefit corporation's
 16 26 board of directors, in addition to its fiduciary duty to make
 16 27 decisions based on financial interests, to also consider
 16 28 factors associated with creating general public benefit or
 16 29 furthering a specific public benefit, or other beneficial goal.
 16 30 The bill limits a director's personal liability due to any
 16 31 failure of the benefit corporation to accomplish a general or
 16 32 specific public benefit purpose.
 16 33    LEGAL ACTIONS.  The bill prohibits a person from bringing an
 16 34 action against a benefit corporation or its directors, except
 16 35 in a benefit enforcement proceeding. A benefit enforcement
 17  1 proceeding can only be commenced by the benefit corporation
 17  2 or derivatively by a person or group that holds shares in
 17  3 the corporation or an equity interest in the corporation, by
 17  4 a director, or by any other person or group provided in the
 17  5 articles of incorporation.
 17  6    BENEFIT DIRECTOR AND OFFICER.  The bill requires a public
 17  7 corporation's board of directors to include a benefit director.
 17  8 A privately held benefit corporation's board may include
 17  9 such director. Such director must be independent, having
 17 10 no material relationship with the benefit corporation.  The
 17 11 bill provides that a benefit corporation may have a benefit
 17 12 officer who is charged with overseeing the creation of the
 17 13 corporation's general public benefit or a specific public
 17 14 benefit.

 17 10 no material relationship with the benefit corporation.  The
 17 11 bill provides that a benefit corporation may have a benefit
 17 12 officer who is charged with overseeing the creation of the
 17 13 corporation's general public benefit or a specific public
 17 14 benefit.
 17 15    REPORT.  The bill requires a benefit corporation to prepare
 17 16 an annual benefit report to its shareholders. The report must
 17 17 include information regarding the third=party standard used
 17 18 to  prepare the benefit report, the ways in which the benefit
 17 19 corporation pursued its general and specific public benefits,
 17 20 and an assessment of the overall social and environmental
 17 21 performance of the benefit corporation indicating whether
 17 22 the benefit corporation pursued its general or any specific
 17 23 public benefit purpose. The bill also requires the benefit
 17 24 corporation to file the benefit report with the secretary of
 17 25 state and pay the secretary of state a filing fee.
